choices.text: The test is contraindicated in patients with congenital absence of the external auditory canal
It allows individual assessment of each labyrinth by stimulating one side at a time
It can be used when caloric testing is not feasible due to canal malformation
Normal post-rotation nystagmus lasts less than 10 seconds

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rotation test (Barany's chair test) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It can be used when caloric testing is not feasible due to canal malformation

 

  • The Barany's rotation test is useful in situations like congenital canal aplasia, where caloric tests (which depend on ear canal irrigation) cannot be performed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The test is contraindicated in patients with congenital absence of the external auditory canal: Incorrect. The rotation test is especially useful in congenital abnormalities where the ear canal is absent or malformed, making caloric testing impossible.

 

Option B. It allows individual assessment of each labyrinth by stimulating one side at a time: Incorrect. A major limitation of this test is that it stimulates both labyrinths simultaneously, so individual assessment is not possible.

 

Option D. Normal post-rotation nystagmus lasts less than 10 seconds: Incorrect. Normal duration of nystagmus following the rotation test is about 25–40 seconds, not less than 10 seconds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rotation test is a valuable vestibular assessment when caloric testing is not feasible, especially in congenital malformations where the external ear canal has not developed.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 44

choices.text: It assesses cochlear function by irrigating the external auditory canal with warm water
A normal response is absence of nystagmus even after 40 mL of cold water irrigation
If nystagmus is elicited only after 20 mL of ice water, the labyrinth is considered hyperactive
No nystagmus even after 40 mL of ice water irrigation suggests a dead labyrinth

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Modified Kobrak test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No nystagmus even after 40 mL of ice water irrigation suggests a dead labyrinth

 

  • If no vestibular response (nystagmus) is observed even after irrigating with 40 mL, the labyrinth is considered nonfunctional (dead).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It assesses cochlear function by irrigating the external auditory canal with warm water: Incorrect. The Modified Kobrak test evaluates vestibular (not cochlear) function, specifically the horizontal semicircular canal. It uses ice water, not warm water.

 

Option B. A normal response is absence of nystagmus even after 40 mL of cold water irrigation: Incorrect. Normally, nystagmus beating to the opposite ear is seen with just 5 mL of ice water. No response even after 40 mL suggests absent vestibular function, i.e., a dead labyrinth.

 

Option C. If nystagmus is elicited only after 20 mL of ice water, the labyrinth is considered hyperactive: Incorrect. A delayed response, requiring more than 5 mL, indicates hypoactive labyrinth, not hyperactive. Hyperactivity would present with exaggerated response to minimal stimulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Modified Kobrak test, absence of nystagmus even after 40 mL of ice water irrigation indicates a dead labyrinth.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 43

choices.text: Nystagmus present only when looking in the direction of fast phase
Stronger than 2nd-degree nystagmus and seen even when looking in the direction of slow phase
Seen only when the patient looks straight ahead
Present in central lesions and suppressed with optic fixation

questions.text: According to Alexander’s law, which of the following correctly describes 3rd-degree nystagmus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stronger than 2nd-degree nystagmus and seen even when looking in the direction of slow phase

 

  • 3rd-degree nystagmus is the most intense form, visible even when the patient looks toward the slow phase, indicating more severe vestibular dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nystagmus present only when looking in the direction of fast phase: Incorrect. This defines 1st-degree nystagmus, which is weak and only present when looking toward the fast component.

 

Option C. Seen only when the patient looks straight ahead: Incorrect. That describes 2nd-degree nystagmus, which is stronger than 1st-degree and present in primary gaze.

 

Option D. Present in central lesions and suppressed with optic fixation: 
Incorrect. Nystagmus due to central lesions often does not follow Alexander’s law and cannot be suppressed by optic fixation. The table specifically applies to peripheral vestibular nystagmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third-degree nystagmus is the most intense form and is present even when the patient looks in the direction of the slow component, as per Alexander’s law.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 42

choices.text: It helps differentiate cochlear from vestibular dysfunction
It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ
The test is performed with the patient seated and eyes open
Normally, the patient sways away from the side of anodal stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the galvanic test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ

 

  • This is the only vestibular test that helps in differentiating end organ (labyrinthine) lesions from vestibular nerve lesions by observing the postural sway in response to electrical stimulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It helps differentiate cochlear from vestibular dysfunction: Incorrect. The galvanic test is specific for the vestibular system and helps differentiate lesions of the vestibular nerve from those of the end organ (labyrinth). It does not assess cochlear function.

 

Option C. The test is performed with the patient seated and eyes open: Incorrect. The test is done with the patient standing, eyes closed, and arms outstretched to best assess postural sway and eliminate visual compensation.

 

Option D. Normally, the patient sways away from the side of anodal stimulation: Incorrect. Normally, the patient sways toward the side of the anodal current, due to altered vestibular input.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The galvanic test is a vestibular assessment that helps differentiate end organ (labyrinthine) lesions from vestibular nerve lesions by evaluating postural sway in response to anodal stimulation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 44

choices.text: Speech reception threshold (SRT) is better than pure tone average (PTA) by 5 dB
Shadow curve is present during bone conduction testing in unilateral hearing loss
Stenger test is positive when the patient denies hearing louder sound in the feigned deaf ear
Electric response audiometry confirms no auditory activity in patients with NOHL

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most suggestive of nonorganic hearing loss (NOHL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stenger test is positive when the patient denies hearing louder sound in the feigned deaf ear

 

  • A positive Stenger test is pathognomonic for NOHL. In this test, when a louder sound is presented to the feigned deaf ear and a softer one to the normal ear, the patient should hear the louder sound if genuinely deaf in one ear. If they deny hearing anything, it implies malingering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Speech reception threshold (SRT) is better than pure tone average (PTA) by 5 dB: Incorrect. A difference of up to 10 dB between SRT and PTA is considered normal. A difference >10 dB, especially where SRT is better than PTA, raises suspicion of NOHL.

 

Option B. Shadow curve is present during bone conduction testing in unilateral hearing loss: Incorrect. The absence of a shadow curve during unmasked bone conduction testing (due to transcranial stimulation) in a patient with claimed unilateral deafness is diagnostic of NOHL.

 

Option D. Electric response audiometry confirms no auditory activity in patients with NOHL: Incorrect. In NOHL, Electric Response Audiometry (ERA) typically shows normal neural responses, even when the patient claims deafness, thus confirming true auditory function and helping rule out organic causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Stenger test, where a patient denies hearing a louder sound in the feigned deaf ear, is diagnostic of nonorganic hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 36

choices.text: The permissible daytime noise limit in a residential area is 65 dB(A) Leq
The permissible night-time noise limit in a silent zone is 45 dB(A) Leq
The permissible daytime noise limit in an industrial area is 75 dB(A) Leq
The permissible night-time noise limit in a commercial area is 70 dB(A) Leq

questions.text: According to the Noise Pollution (Regulation and Control) Rules 2000 by the Ministry of Environment and Forest, Govt. of India, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The permissible daytime noise limit in an industrial area is 75 dB(A) Leq

 

  • As per the table, industrial zones are permitted a maximum of 75 dB(A) Leq during the day (6 am to 10 pm).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The permissible daytime noise limit in a residential area is 65 dB(A) Leq: Incorrect. The residential zone has a daytime limit of 55 dB(A) Leq, not 65. The 65 dB limit applies to commercial zones.

 

Option B. The permissible night-time noise limit in a silent zone is 45 dB(A) Leq: Incorrect. In a silent zone, the night-time permissible limit is 40 dB(A) Leq, not 45.

 

Option D. The permissible night-time noise limit in a commercial area is 70 dB(A) Leq: Incorrect. The commercial zone night-time limit is 55 dB(A) Leq, not 70.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per Noise Pollution Rules 2000, the permissible daytime noise limit in industrial areas is 75 dB(A) Leq.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 34

choices.text: Furosemide causes irreversible damage to the outer hair cells in all cases
Neomycin and kanamycin are primarily vestibulotoxic drugs
Deferoxamine can cause high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in children
Salicylate-induced hearing loss is due to hair cell destruction seen on electron microscopy

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ototoxicity is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deferoxamine can cause high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in children

 

  • Deferoxamine, an iron-chelating agent, causes high-frequency SNHL due to neurotoxicity. Children, especially those with thalassemia receiving chronic transfusions, are particularly vulnerable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide causes irreversible damage to the outer hair cells in all cases: Incorrect. Furosemide (a loop diuretic) may cause reversible hearing loss in most cases due to edema of the stria vascularis, although permanent damage can occur in some individuals.

 

Option B. Neomycin and kanamycin are primarily vestibulotoxic drugs: Incorrect. These drugs are cochleotoxic, not vestibulotoxic. They selectively damage the outer hair cells, beginning at the basal turn of the cochlea.

 

Option D. Salicylate-induced hearing loss is due to hair cell destruction seen on electron microscopy: Incorrect. Although salicylates can cause tinnitus and high-frequency SNHL, there is no morphological evidence of hair cell destruction on microscopy. The mechanism is likely biochemical, and the loss is reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deferoxamine is an ototoxic agent that can cause high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, especially in children receiving long-term therapy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 33

choices.text: Distraction test is reliable only after 12 months of age when the child develops speech
It uses pure tone audiometry to assess hearing thresholds in infants
It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound
Only high-frequency sounds are used, such as 8 kHz rattles or whistles

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding distraction techniques used in pediatric hearing assessment is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound

 

  • At 6–7 months, a child typically develops the ability to turn their head toward sound, making this the ideal age for distraction testing. The examiner observes whether the child responds to a sound presented from behind or the side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distraction test is reliable only after 12 months of age when the child develops speech: Incorrect. Distraction techniques are specifically used around 6–7 months of age when the child starts localizing sound by turning the head, not after 12 months.

 

Option B. It uses pure tone audiometry to assess hearing thresholds in infants: Incorrect. Distraction testing is a behavioral method, not based on pure tones or thresholds. It relies on the child's response to various sound stimuli, not standard audiometric procedures.

 

Option D. Only high-frequency sounds are used, such as 8 kHz rattles or whistles: Incorrect. A range of sounds is used in distraction testing: high-frequency rattles (8 kHz), low-frequency hums, whispered "S" sounds, xylophones, warbled tones, and narrow band noise (500–4000 Hz).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distraction testing is performed at 6–7 months of age to assess hearing by observing the child’s head-turning response to various sound stimuli presented out of sight.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: Binaural tests are typically abnormal in cortical lesions
Dichotic tests present distorted speech to both ears simultaneously
Monotic tests assess difficulty in understanding distorted speech and are affected in cortical lesions
Central auditory tests are routinely used as part of standard audiological assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding central auditory tests is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monotic tests assess difficulty in understanding distorted speech and are affected in cortical lesions

 

Monotic tests assess difficulty in understanding distorted speech and are affected in cortical lesions: Correct. Monotic tests present distorted speech to one ear and are particularly affected in patients with cortical or brain lesions, making it a relevant tool for central auditory processing disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binaural tests are typically abnormal in cortical lesions: Incorrect. Binaural tests, such as the binaural masking level difference test, are normal in cortical lesions but abnormal in brainstem lesions, helping localize lesions below the cortex.

 

Option B. Dichotic tests present distorted speech to both ears simultaneously: Incorrect. In dichotic tests, two different speech messages are presented simultaneously, one to each ear, not distorted speech. They're used to detect temporal lobe lesions, especially when the deficit is seen in the ear opposite to the side of the lesion.

 

Option D. Central auditory tests are routinely used as part of standard audiological assessment: Incorrect. These tests are not routinely used in standard audiological evaluations but are applied selectively, particularly when central auditory dysfunction is suspected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monotic tests help identify central auditory dysfunction by evaluating how well distorted speech is understood, and are particularly affected in cortical brain lesions.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 28

choices.text: A tone of 1000 Hz is presented at 20 dB above threshold for 60 seconds to assess cochlear pathology
A decay of more than 25 dB suggests a cochlear lesion
A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds
The test is primarily used to assess the presence of middle ear pathology

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Threshold Tone Decay Test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds

 

  • This accurately describes the procedure of the Threshold Tone Decay Test, which is used to assess nerve fatigue and detect retrocochlear lesions. The tone is increased by 5 dB increments if the patient cannot hear it continuously for 60 seconds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tone of 1000 Hz is presented at 20 dB above threshold for 60 seconds to assess cochlear pathology: Incorrect. The Threshold Tone Decay Test typically uses a 4000 Hz tone, not 1000 Hz, and it is initially presented at 5 dB above the hearing threshold, not 20 dB.

 

Option B. A decay of more than 25 dB suggests a cochlear lesion: Incorrect. A tone decay greater than 25 dB is diagnostic of a retrocochlear lesion (e.g., vestibular schwannoma), not cochlear pathology.

 

Option D. The test is primarily used to assess the presence of middle ear pathology: Incorrect. Middle ear pathology (e.g., otitis media) typically affects conductive hearing. This test is specifically used to detect retrocochlear (nerve) pathology, not middle ear disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Threshold Tone Decay Test detects retrocochlear lesions by measuring how much above threshold a 4000 Hz tone must be presented for the patient to hear it continuously for 60 seconds.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: Recruitment is typically seen in retrocochlear lesions such as vestibular schwannoma
It refers to improved hearing of soft sounds in the affected ear
Recruitment is detected using the Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test and is common in cochlear lesions like Ménière’s disease
Patients with recruitment are ideal candidates for hearing aids

questions.text: Which of the following statements about recruitment is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recruitment is detected using the Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test and is common in cochlear lesions like Ménière’s disease

 

  • The Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test compares perceived loudness in the normal ear and the affected ear. Recruitment is positive in cochlear lesions, where the loudness in the affected ear rapidly catches up to or even exceeds that in the normal ear as intensity increases.

 

 

Non-recruiting ear: The initial 20 dB loudness difference between the right and left ear remains consistent across all intensity levels.

 

Recruiting ear (right side): Although there was an initial 30 dB difference, by 80 dB the right ear perceives sound equally as loud as the left ear

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recruitment is typically seen in retrocochlear lesions such as vestibular schwannoma: Incorrect. Recruitment is a hallmark of cochlear lesions (like Ménière’s disease and presbycusis), not retrocochlear lesions. In retrocochlear disorders (like acoustic neuroma), recruitment is absent.

 

Option B. It refers to improved hearing of soft sounds in the affected ear: Incorrect. Recruitment does not involve improved hearing of soft sounds. Instead, it refers to the abnormal loudness perception of louder sounds after a threshold—a rapid rise in loudness, not sensitivity to soft sounds.

 

Option D. Patients with recruitment are ideal candidates for hearing aids: Incorrect. Patients with recruitment typically do not tolerate hearing aids well, as even moderate sounds may be perceived as uncomfortably loud.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recruitment is an abnormal increase in loudness perception seen in cochlear lesions like Ménière’s disease and is detected using the Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: The central vestibular system includes the utricle, saccule, and semicircular ducts
The peripheral vestibular system is responsible for integrating impulses with other sensory systems
The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS
The peripheral vestibular system includes the cochlea and auditory nerve

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the division of the vestibular system?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS

 

  • The central vestibular system includes:
    • Vestibular nuclei (superior, medial, lateral, descending)
    • Fibre tracts such as the medial longitudinal bundle, vestibulospinal tract, and vestibulocerebellar connections
  • These coordinate reflexes and maintain body balance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The central vestibular system includes the utricle, saccule, and semicircular ducts: Incorrect. These structures are part of the peripheral vestibular system, not central. They are components of the membranous labyrinth that detect motion and orientation.

 

Option B. The peripheral vestibular system is responsible for integrating impulses with other sensory systems: Incorrect. The integration of vestibular information with visual, proprioceptive, and cerebellar input is the role of the central vestibular system, not peripheral.

 

Option D. The peripheral vestibular system includes the cochlea and auditory nerve: Incorrect. The cochlea and auditory nerve are part of the auditory system, not the vestibular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The central vestibular system consists of vestibular nuclei and fibre tracts in the CNS, which integrate vestibular impulses to maintain body balance.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 17

choices.text: The cochlea makes one complete turn around the modiolus and forms the promontory
The non-ampullated ends of the superior and lateral semicircular canals form the crus commune
The vestibule contains openings for all three semicircular canals and lodges both saccule and utricle
The osseous spiral lamina completely divides the bony cochlea into two separate chambers

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the bony labyrinth is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The vestibule contains openings for all three semicircular canals and lodges both saccule and utricle

 

  • The vestibule is the central chamber of the bony labyrinth. It:
    • Lodges the saccule in the spherical recess
    • Lodges the utricle in the elliptical recess
    • Receives five openings from the three semicircular canals

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The cochlea makes one complete turn around the modiolus and forms the promontory: Incorrect. The bony cochlea makes 2.5 to 2.75 turns around the modiolus. The promontory is formed by the basal turn, but it's not just a single turn.

 

Option B. The non-ampullated ends of the superior and lateral semicircular canals form the crus commune: Incorrect. The crus commune is formed by the non-ampullated ends of the superior and posterior semicircular canals, not the lateral canal.

 

Option D. The osseous spiral lamina completely divides the bony cochlea into two separate chambers: Incorrect. The osseous spiral lamina only incompletely divides the bony cochlea and provides attachment to the basilar membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vestibule is the central chamber of the bony labyrinth that receives five semicircular canal openings and lodges both the saccule and utricle.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 9

choices.text: Wave I of ABR is generated from the cochlear nucleus
ABR is an invasive test used to measure cortical auditory responses
ABR is useful in detecting retrocochlear lesions such as acoustic neuroma
ABR primarily evaluates hearing sensitivity below 500 Hz

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) testing is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABR is useful in detecting retrocochlear lesions such as acoustic neuroma

 

  • ABR helps identify retrocochlear pathologies, especially acoustic neuroma, by analyzing latencies and interwave delays, particularly between Wave I and Wave V.

 

 

Brainstem Auditory Evoked Potentials (BAEP):

 

(a) Wave amplitude is measured in microvolts (μV), from the peak of a wave to the peak of the following trough.

 

(b) Absolute peak latency refers to the time (in milliseconds) from the onset of the auditory click stimulus to the appearance of a specific wave.

 

(c) Interpeak latency is the time interval (in milliseconds) between two specific waves—such as I–III, III–V, or I–V—and is compared with standard reference values (I–III: 2.0 ms; III–V: 2.0 ms; I–V: 4.0 ms).

 

(d) Interaural peak latency is the difference in latency of the same wave between both ears, typically used to assess unilateral pathologies like acoustic neuroma by comparing wave V latency across ears.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wave I of ABR is generated from the cochlear nucleus: Incorrect. Wave I originates from the distal part of the cochlear nerve (CN VIII), not from the cochlear nucleus. The cochlear nucleus is the generator of Wave III.

 

Option B. ABR is an invasive test used to measure cortical auditory responses: Incorrect. ABR is a non-invasive test that measures brainstem auditory responses, not cortical potentials. It uses surface electrodes to detect activity within the first 10 milliseconds after auditory stimulation.

 

Option D. ABR primarily evaluates hearing sensitivity below 500 Hz: Incorrect. ABR primarily tests hearing in the range of 1000–4000 Hz, which corresponds to the frequencies used in click stimuli or tone bursts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABR is a non-invasive test that evaluates auditory pathway integrity and is especially useful in diagnosing retrocochlear pathologies such as acoustic neuroma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration
Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation
Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window
Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly explains the importance of phase differential between the oval and round windows in the auditory system?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

 

  • The phase differential between the oval and round windows—achieved via the ossicular chain, tympanic membrane, and air cushion around the round window—ensures that when compression hits the oval window, the round window bulges outward (rarefaction). This creates the necessary fluid movement in the cochlea for sound transduction and contributes about 4 dB to hearing efficiency when the tympanic membrane is intact.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration: Incorrect. If sound waves reach both windows simultaneously, the compressions and rarefactions would cancel each other out, leading to no effective movement of perilymph, and hence no hearing.

 

Option B. Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation: Incorrect. The ossicular chain transmits sound to the oval window, not the round window. The round window acts as a pressure release point.

 

Option C. Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window: Incorrect. Compression at the oval window is paired with rarefaction at the round window, creating fluid displacement inside the cochlea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase differential between the oval and round windows ensures alternate compression and rarefaction, preventing cancellation of waves and enabling perilymph movement for effective hearing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13.

choices.text: Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture
The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs
Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal
Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the physiological basis for body equilibrium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

 

  • The body maintains equilibrium using a push-pull mechanism between bilateral vestibular systems. If one side becomes hyperactive or hypoactive, balance is disturbed. Reflexes like the:
    • Vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) stabilize gaze
    • Vestibulocervical reflex controls head position
    • Vestibulospinal reflex maintains trunk and limb posture
      Together, they ensure dynamic correction of posture and gaze.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture: Incorrect. Balance is a multisensory function, involving vestibular, visual, and somatosensory systems. Relying on vision alone is insufficient and does not explain conditions like vestibular ataxia.

 

Option B. The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs: Incorrect. The vestibular system integrates input from visual and somatosensory systems, especially during head movement or positional changes. It does not act in isolation.

 

Option D. Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance: Incorrect. A static imbalance due to vestibular dysfunction (e.g. unilateral vestibulopathy) can cause vertigo and ataxia even at rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Equilibrium is maintained by a bilateral vestibular push-pull system integrated with visual and somatosensory input, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal responses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 18

choices.text: SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma
The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments
A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology
Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology

 

  • Patients with cochlear hearing loss (e.g., Ménière’s disease, presbycusis) have increased sensitivity to small intensity changes, resulting in SISI scores of 70–100%, which is diagnostic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma: Incorrect. Retrocochlear (nerve) lesions typically produce low SISI scores (0–20%) because these patients have poor sensitivity to small intensity changes.

 

Option B. The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments: Incorrect. In the SISI test, a continuous pure tone is presented 20 dB above threshold, and every 5 seconds a 1 dB increment (blip) is introduced — not 5 dB.

 

Option D. Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%: Incorrect. In conductive hearing loss, SISI scores are usually <15%, as sound conduction is impaired but cochlear function remains intact.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A SISI score of 70–100% is indicative of cochlear pathology, helping differentiate it from retrocochlear and conductive causes of hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: ASSR uses transient stimuli like clicks and tone bursts to generate a response
ASSR is unable to detect hearing loss greater than 80 dB in infants
ASSR provides frequency-specific audiograms using modulated pure tones
ASSR is not suitable for early selection of candidates for cochlear implantation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Auditory Steady State Response (ASSR) is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ASSR provides frequency-specific audiograms using modulated pure tones

 

  • ASSR generates a frequency-specific audiogram using steady-state signals that are amplitude and frequency modulated, making it ideal for precise hearing threshold assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASSR uses transient stimuli like clicks and tone bursts to generate a response: Incorrect. ABR uses transient stimuli such as clicks or tone bursts. In contrast, ASSR uses steady-state pure tone signals that are rapidly modulated in amplitude and frequency.

 

Option B. ASSR is unable to detect hearing loss greater than 80 dB in infants: Incorrect. One of the main advantages of ASSR over ABR is that it can detect hearing losses exceeding 80 dB, making it valuable in severe to profoundly deaf infants.

 

Option D. ASSR is not suitable for early selection of candidates for cochlear implantation: Incorrect. ASSR is especially useful in early detection of profound hearing loss and helps in identifying infants who may benefit from cochlear implantation at a young age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASSR uses modulated pure tone signals to generate frequency-specific audiograms and is effective in detecting hearing losses above 80 dB, aiding early cochlear implant candidacy decisions.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: Moro’s reflex – blinking in response to sound
Cessation reflex – startle reflex with head extension and limb movement
Cochleopalpebral reflex – blinking in response to loud sound
Behavioural observation audiometry – uses pure tone thresholds to plot audiograms in infants

questions.text: Which of the following responses is correctly matched with its behavioral observation audiometry reflex in infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cochleopalpebral reflex – blinking in response to loud sound

 

  • In cochleopalpebral reflex, the infant blinks in response to a loud sound, making it a useful indicator of auditory function in young infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moro’s reflex – blinking in response to sound: Incorrect. Moro’s reflex is a startle response that includes sudden limb movement and head extension, not blinking.

 

Option B. Cessation reflex – startle reflex with head extension and limb movement: Incorrect. The cessation reflex is when an infant stops activity or starts crying in response to a loud sound, not a startle reflex. The startle reflex described here belongs to Moro’s reflex.

 

Option D. Behavioural observation audiometry – uses pure tone thresholds to plot audiograms in infants: Incorrect. Behavioural Observation Audiometry (BOA) relies on observing changes in infant behavior (e.g., eye widening, facial grimace, reflexes), not on pure tone audiometry, which requires more cooperation and is used in older children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cochleopalpebral reflex is a blink response to loud sound used in behavioral observation audiometry to assess hearing in infants.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss with negative Rinne and positive Weber
Positive Hennebert’s sign without an actual fistula
Sensorineural hearing loss due to vestibular schwannoma
Negative FTA-ABS and RPR tests in CSF

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most characteristically associated with otosyphilis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Positive Hennebert’s sign without an actual fistula

 

  • Hennebert’s sign is a false-positive fistula test seen in otosyphilis due to fibrous adhesions between the stapes footplate and membranous labyrinth—there is no actual fistula present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss with negative Rinne and positive Weber: Incorrect. Otosyphilis causes sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive. Rinne is positive, and Weber typically lateralizes to the better ear.

 

Option C. Sensorineural hearing loss due to vestibular schwannoma: Incorrect. While vestibular schwannoma does cause SNHL, it is not related to otosyphilis. The question is asking about otosyphilis-specific findings.

 

Option D. Negative FTA-ABS and RPR tests in CSF: Incorrect. These serologic tests (FTA-ABS, VDRL, RPR) are often positive in otosyphilis, especially when drawn from CSF, and aid in confirming the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Hennebert’s sign without an actual fistula is a classic finding in otosyphilis due to fibrous adhesions in the inner ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 33

choices.text: Temporary threshold shift (TTS) usually lasts several months before recovery
Noise at frequencies between 2000–3000 Hz is particularly damaging to the cochlea
Continuous noise is less harmful than interrupted noise
The intensity of noise does not affect the duration of safe exposure

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Noise at frequencies between 2000–3000 Hz is particularly damaging to the cochlea

 

  • This frequency range (2–3 kHz) is most damaging to the inner ear and is often the first affected in Noise-Induced Hearing Loss, especially in occupational settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporary threshold shift (TTS) usually lasts several months before recovery: Incorrect. Temporary Threshold Shift (TTS) is short-term, typically resolving within minutes to hours, though in some cases it may take up to 2 weeks, not several months.

 

Option C. Continuous noise is less harmful than interrupted noise: Incorrect. Continuous noise is more harmful than interrupted noise, as the ear gets no time to recover, increasing the risk of both TTS and PTS.

 

Option D. The intensity of noise does not affect the duration of safe exposure: Incorrect. As the intensity increases, the permissible duration for safe exposure decreases significantly, following occupational safety guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noise in the 2000–3000 Hz frequency range is particularly damaging to the cochlea and commonly contributes to noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 34

choices.text: AIED typically presents with sudden, unilateral conductive hearing loss
Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for all patients diagnosed with AIED
Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness
Progression is defined as a threshold shift of 5 dB at any frequency on follow-up audiograms

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness

 

  • The Western blot assay for anti-Hsp70 antibodies is not specific but correlates with active disease and response to steroids, making it a useful supportive diagnostic marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIED typically presents with sudden, unilateral conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. AIED causes progressive, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, not sudden or conductive loss. Vestibular symptoms like vertigo may also be present.

 

Option B. Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for all patients diagnosed with AIED: Incorrect. The first-line treatment is prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day). Methotrexate is reserved for steroid non-responders or those who cannot tolerate steroids.

 

Option D. Progression is defined as a threshold shift of 5 dB at any frequency on follow-up audiograms: Incorrect. According to Moscicki's criteria, progression is defined as a ≥15 dB shift at one frequency or ≥10 dB at two or more consecutive frequencies, or a significant drop in speech discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presence of anti-Hsp70 antibodies in autoimmune inner ear disease may correlate with active disease and steroid responsiveness, aiding in diagnosis and treatment planning.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 36

choices.text: A positive Romberg test with eyes open indicates peripheral vestibular dysfunction
In peripheral vestibular lesions, sway occurs away from the side of the lesion
Inability to perform the sharpened Romberg test suggests vestibular impairment
Romberg test is primarily used to assess cerebellar function

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Romberg test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inability to perform the sharpened Romberg test suggests vestibular impairment

 

  • The sharpened Romberg test (standing with heel-to-toe and arms folded) is a more sensitive variation, and inability to maintain balance during this test indicates vestibular dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive Romberg test with eyes open indicates peripheral vestibular dysfunction: Incorrect. A positive Romberg test typically manifests only when the eyes are closed, because visual input compensates for vestibular or proprioceptive deficits when the eyes are open. Instability with eyes open suggests a cerebellar rather than vestibular issue.

 

Option B. In peripheral vestibular lesions, sway occurs away from the side of the lesion: Incorrect. In peripheral vestibular lesions, sway typically occurs toward the side of the lesion, not away from it.

 

Option D. Romberg test is primarily used to assess cerebellar function: 
Incorrect. The Romberg test assesses proprioceptive and vestibular function, not cerebellar function. Cerebellar ataxia usually presents with instability even with eyes open, making Romberg test non-specific for cerebellar lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inability to perform the sharpened Romberg test indicates vestibular system dysfunction, especially in cases where visual compensation is removed.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 41

choices.text: Immediate onset of nystagmus, direction changing, non-fatiguable
Nystagmus with no vertigo and variable direction in each head position
Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable
Nystagmus lasting over 1 minute, present in straight head-hanging position only

questions.text: Which of the following findings during a Hallpike manoeuvre is most suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) due to a peripheral cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable

 

  • These are hallmark features of BPPV, a peripheral vestibular disorder. The latency, brief duration, fixed direction, and fatiguability of nystagmus strongly support a peripheral origin, especially involving the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate onset of nystagmus, direction changing, non-fatiguable: Incorrect. These features are characteristic of central positional vertigo, often due to cerebellar or brainstem lesions (e.g., IVth ventricle tumors, MS).

 

Option B. Nystagmus with no vertigo and variable direction in each head position: Incorrect. This pattern is again consistent with a central cause, where nystagmus occurs without associated vertigo and changes direction with head position.

 

Option D. Nystagmus lasting over 1 minute, present in straight head-hanging position only: Incorrect.  Nystagmus of long duration (>1 min) is not typical of BPPV and may point toward a central cause. Also, BPPV is diagnosed by testing multiple positions, not just straight head-hanging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BPPV is indicated by nystagmus with a latency of 2–20 seconds, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguability on repeated Hallpike manoeuvre testing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 42

choices.text: ENG is based on detecting auditory evoked potentials from the cochlea
ENG cannot detect nystagmus that is not visible to the naked eye
ENG uses corneoretinal potentials recorded via electrodes placed around the eyes
ENG is only useful for recording spontaneous nystagmus and not stimulus-induced types

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Electronystagmography (ENG) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ENG uses corneoretinal potentials recorded via electrodes placed around the eyes

 

  • ENG works by detecting corneoretinal potentials — the eye acts as a dipole with the cornea more positive than the retina. Electrodes placed around the eyes record changes in potential during eye movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ENG is based on detecting auditory evoked potentials from the cochlea: Incorrect. That describes auditory evoked potential tests, not ENG. ENG assesses vestibular function and eye movement, not auditory potentials.

 

Option B. ENG cannot detect nystagmus that is not visible to the naked eye: Incorrect. One of the key advantages of ENG is its ability to detect even subtle nystagmus, including those not visible to the naked eye.

 

Option D. ENG is only useful for recording spontaneous nystagmus and not stimulus-induced types: Incorrect. ENG can record both spontaneous and induced nystagmus, such as caloric, positional, rotational, or optokinetic types, making it a comprehensive vestibular assessment tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electronystagmography records eye movements by detecting corneoretinal potentials using electrodes and can identify both spontaneous and stimulus-induced nystagmus, including those not visible to the naked eye.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 44

choices.text: Adiadochokinesia and abnormal finger–nose test
Dysmetria and rebound phenomenon
Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait
Hemiplegia with spasticity and positive Babinski sign

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most consistent with midline cerebellar dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait

 

  • These are classic features of midline cerebellar dysfunction, often affecting the vermis. Such patients have difficulty maintaining upright posture, fall in any direction, and have impaired balance while walking or turning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adiadochokinesia and abnormal finger–nose test: Incorrect. These are signs of hemispheric cerebellar dysfunction, not midline. They indicate problems with coordination of limbs.

 

Option B. Dysmetria and rebound phenomenon:  Incorrect. Like Option A, these are also features of cerebellar hemisphere lesions, affecting voluntary limb control and force regulation.

 

Option D. Hemiplegia with spasticity and positive Babinski sign: Incorrect. These signs point to upper motor neuron lesions, especially involving the corticospinal tract, and are not cerebellar in origin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Midline cerebellar dysfunction typically presents with truncal ataxia, wide-based gait, falls in any direction, and difficulty turning while walking.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 42

choices.text: Acoustic trauma always presents with a temporary threshold shift that later becomes permanent
Impulse noise from gunfire can reach up to 100 dB SPL, which is usually safe for the cochlea
Exposure to impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the organ of Corti
Acoustic trauma primarily affects the middle ear and spares the cochlea

questions.text: Which of the following statements about acoustic trauma is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exposure to impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the organ of Corti

 

  • Impulse noise (≥140 dB), even for durations as short as 0.2 milliseconds, can rupture Reissner’s membrane, damage hair cells, and cause mixing of perilymph and endolymph, leading to permanent SNHL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acoustic trauma always presents with a temporary threshold shift that later becomes permanent: Incorrect. Acoustic trauma can cause permanent damage even without a preceding temporary threshold shift, especially if the sound is extremely intense and brief, such as in explosions.

 

Option B. Impulse noise from gunfire can reach up to 100 dB SPL, which is usually safe for the cochlea: Incorrect. Noise from gunfire or explosions can reach 140–170 dB SPL, well above the safe limit, and is capable of causing immediate, irreversible damage.

 

Option D. Acoustic trauma primarily affects the middle ear and spares the cochlea: Incorrect. While a blast injury may also damage the tympanic membrane and ossicles, acoustic trauma primarily affects the cochlea, especially the organ of Corti.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic trauma from impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the cochlea, particularly the organ of Corti, leading to permanent sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 34

choices.text: SNHL is typically associated with an air-bone gap on audiometry
Speech discrimination scores are usually preserved in SNHL
SNHL often affects high frequencies and may show poor speech discrimination
Rinne test is negative in SNHL due to reduced bone conduction

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SNHL often affects high frequencies and may show poor speech discrimination

 

  • SNHL commonly affects high frequencies first and is associated with difficulty hearing in noisy environments and poor speech discrimination. These are classic hallmarks of cochlear involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SNHL is typically associated with an air-bone gap on audiometry: 
Incorrect. SNHL does not show an air-bone gap on audiometry because both air and bone conduction are reduced equally, unlike in conductive hearing loss where the gap is present.

 

Option B. Speech discrimination scores are usually preserved in SNHL: Incorrect. In SNHL, especially when cochlear or retrocochlear, speech discrimination is often poor, even when hearing thresholds may appear only moderately elevated.

 

Option D. Rinne test is negative in SNHL due to reduced bone conduction: Incorrect. In SNHL, the Rinne test is positive (AC > BC), even though bone conduction is reduced. A negative Rinne is seen in conductive hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensorineural hearing loss often affects high frequencies and is associated with poor speech discrimination and no air-bone gap on audiometry.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 32

choices.text: OAEs are absent in auditory neuropathy due to damage to cochlear hair cells
Distortion Product OAEs (DPOAEs) are evoked using single click stimuli at 80–85 dB SPL
OAEs are useful in distinguishing cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss
OAEs disappear in VIIIth nerve pathology due to nerve dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OAEs are useful in distinguishing cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss

 

  • OAEs help differentiate cochlear lesions (e.g., ototoxicity – OAEs absent) from retrocochlear lesions (e.g., auditory neuropathy – OAEs preserved). This makes them valuable in identifying the site of pathology.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OAEs are absent in auditory neuropathy due to damage to cochlear hair cells: Incorrect. In auditory neuropathy, the cochlear hair cells are normal, so OAEs are preserved despite VIIIth nerve dysfunction. Hence, OAEs are present, while ABR is abnormal or absent.

 

Option B. Distortion Product OAEs (DPOAEs) are evoked using single click stimuli at 80–85 dB SPL: Incorrect. This describes Transient Evoked OAEs (TEOAEs). Distortion Product OAEs (DPOAEs) are evoked by two simultaneous tones, not single clicks.

 

 

Option D. OAEs disappear in VIIIth nerve pathology due to nerve dysfunction: Incorrect. OAEs do not disappear in pure VIIIth nerve pathology, as long as the outer hair cells of the cochlea are intact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OAEs help differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss by being absent in cochlear pathology but preserved in retrocochlear disorders like auditory neuropathy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 28

choices.text: Direct overstimulation of the cochlear nerve due to loud sounds
Isolated dysfunction of the cerebellum without vestibular input
Mismatch of inputs from visual, vestibular, and somatosensory systems reaching vestibular nuclei and cerebellum
Excess endolymph production in the semicircular canals during motion

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the cause of motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mismatch of inputs from visual, vestibular, and somatosensory systems reaching vestibular nuclei and cerebellum

 

  • Motion sickness is caused by a conflict or mismatch between the visual, vestibular (labyrinthine), and somatosensory systems. For example, when you read in a moving car, your eyes see still text, but your vestibular system senses motion, causing conflicting input to vestibular nuclei and cerebellum, which leads to nausea, vomiting, pallor, and sweating.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct overstimulation of the cochlear nerve due to loud sounds: Incorrect. Motion sickness is unrelated to auditory (cochlear) input. It’s a vestibular-related phenomenon, not an auditory one.

 

Option B. Isolated dysfunction of the cerebellum without vestibular input: Incorrect. The cerebellum integrates sensory input, but motion sickness is not caused by isolated cerebellar dysfunction. It arises from conflicting sensory signals.

 

Option D. Excess endolymph production in the semicircular canals during motion: Incorrect. This describes endolymphatic hydrops (as in Ménière’s disease), not motion sickness. Motion sickness is not due to excess endolymph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Motion sickness occurs due to sensory mismatch between visual, vestibular, and somatosensory inputs reaching the vestibular nuclei and cerebellum.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 18

choices.text: All frequencies stimulate the entire length of the basilar membrane uniformly
Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics
Low-frequency sounds stimulate the basal turn of the cochlea, while high frequencies reach the apex
The primary auditory neurons are multipolar and located in the cochlear nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cochlear function and auditory transduction is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics

 

  • Movement of the stapes footplate sets cochlear fluids into motion. This moves the basilar membrane, causing shearing between the basilar and tectorial membranes. This deforms the hair cells, leading to generation of receptor potentials (cochlear microphonics) and the initiation of nerve impulses.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All frequencies stimulate the entire length of the basilar membrane uniformly: Incorrect. According to von Békésy’s travelling wave theory, each sound frequency causes maximum displacement at a specific point along the basilar membrane:

 

  • High-frequency sounds → Basal turn
  • Low-frequency sounds → Apical turn

 

 

Option C. Low-frequency sounds stimulate the basal turn of the cochlea, while high frequencies reach the apex: Incorrect. It's the opposite:

 

  • High-frequency sounds → Base of cochlea (stiff, narrow part)
  • Low-frequency sounds → Apex of cochlea (wider, more compliant)

 

Option D. The primary auditory neurons are multipolar and located in the cochlear nuclei: Incorrect. Primary auditory neurons are bipolar, and their cell bodies are located in the spiral ganglion, not the cochlear nuclei. Their axons form the cochlear nerve.

 

 

Here is the reframed version of the paragraph with clearer and more natural phrasing, while retaining all the scientific details:

 

From Sound to Neural Signal:

 

Option A. Anatomy of the Ear: Sound waves enter through the pinna, pass along the ear canal, and cause the eardrum to vibrate. These vibrations are transmitted by the ossicles to the oval window, which in turn initiates fluid movement within the cochlea. This fluid movement generates a frequency-specific response based on the tonotopic organization, where each sound frequency resonates at a specific location along the cochlea.

 

Option B. Cochlear Structure: The cochlea consists of three fluid-filled compartments: scala tympani (ST), scala vestibuli (SV), and scala media (SM), which spiral around the central bony core called the modiolus (M). Inside the modiolus lies Rosenthal’s canal (RC), housing the cell bodies (somata) of auditory nerve fibers. These fibers serve as communication lines between the sensory hair cells of the organ of Corti (marked with a star) and the auditory processing centers of the brain.

 

Option C. 3D Visualization: A three-dimensional representation shows 30 colored auditory nerve fibers originating from different cochlear regions—basal (black), middle (green), and apical (red)—spiraling alongside the scala tympani. A 12-channel cochlear implant (light blue) with electrode contacts (gray circles) is shown inserted into the scala tympani, as modeled in our simulations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shearing between the basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, generating cochlear microphonics and initiating auditory transduction based on frequency-specific displacement along the basilar membrane.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13

choices.text: Play audiometry conditions a child to perform a task like placing a block in a bucket upon hearing a sound signal
Play audiometry is only useful in infants below 1 year of age
Play audiometry cannot determine ear-specific hearing thresholds
Play audiometry does not require any reinforcement or reward during the procedure

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Play Audiometry is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Play audiometry conditions a child to perform a task like placing a block in a bucket upon hearing a sound signal

 

  • In play audiometry, children are conditioned to associate a sound stimulus with a specific action, such as placing a marble in a box or a block in a bucket, which is reinforced by praise or reward. It’s effective for children with developmental age of 2–4 or 5 years.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Play audiometry is only useful in infants below 1 year of age: Incorrect. Infants below 1 year cannot follow the conditioned tasks required in play audiometry. It is not suitable for this age group. Instead, tests like OAE or ABR are used in infants.

 

Option C. Play audiometry cannot determine ear-specific hearing thresholds: Incorrect. Play audiometry is performed using headphones or insert earphones, which allows determination of ear-specific hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques.

 

Option D. Play audiometry does not require any reinforcement or reward during the procedure: Incorrect. Positive reinforcement through praise, encouragement, or small rewards is essential to maintain the child’s interest and ensure cooperation during the test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Play audiometry is used in children aged 2–5 years by conditioning them to perform a simple task in response to sound, allowing ear-specific threshold determination with positive reinforcement.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: Viral labyrinthitis commonly spreads from the middle ear through the oval window
Bacterial labyrinthitis cannot occur through CSF pathways
Herpes simplex and influenza are definitively proven to directly invade the inner ear
Sensorineural hearing loss following meningitis is a well-known clinical consequence of bacterial labyrinthitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about labyrinthitis and its etiologies is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss following meningitis is a well-known clinical consequence of bacterial labyrinthitis

 

  • Bacterial meningitis can lead to meningogenic labyrinthitis, causing destruction of the membranous labyrinth, resulting in sensorineural hearing loss, a well-recognized complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral labyrinthitis commonly spreads from the middle ear through the oval window: Incorrect. Viral labyrinthitis spreads hematogenously (via bloodstream), not through the middle ear. Viruses primarily affect the stria vascularis, then the endolymph and organ of Corti.

 

Option B. Bacterial labyrinthitis cannot occur through CSF pathways: Incorrect. Bacterial labyrinthitis can indeed spread via CSF, particularly in meningogenic routes. The infection can reach the labyrinth through cochlear aqueduct, endolymphatic sac, nerves, or blood vessels.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex and influenza are definitively proven to directly invade the inner ear: Incorrect. While viruses like herpes simplex, rubella, and influenza are clinically associated with deafness, direct evidence of labyrinth invasion is lacking, except for viruses like measles, mumps, and CMV, which are well documented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensorineural hearing loss is a recognized complication of bacterial labyrinthitis, especially following meningitis due to destruction of the membranous labyrinth.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 33

choices.text: In neural presbycusis, speech discrimination is preserved despite high-frequency hearing loss
Strial (metabolic) presbycusis typically presents with a sloping audiogram and poor speech discrimination
Cochlear conductive presbycusis is due to stiffening of the basilar membrane and produces a sloping audiogram
Sensory presbycusis begins at the apex of the cochlea and affects low-frequency hearing first

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Presbycusis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cochlear conductive presbycusis is due to stiffening of the basilar membrane and produces a sloping audiogram

 

  • In cochlear conductive presbycusis, the basilar membrane becomes stiff, impairing its motion and leading to a sloping audiogram pattern on testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In neural presbycusis, speech discrimination is preserved despite high-frequency hearing loss:  Incorrect. Neural presbycusis involves degeneration of spiral ganglion cells, resulting in poor speech discrimination that is out of proportion to the degree of pure tone hearing loss.

 

Option B. Strial (metabolic) presbycusis typically presents with a sloping audiogram and poor speech discrimination: Incorrect. Strial/metabolic presbycusis is associated with atrophy of the stria vascularis, shows a flat audiogram, and good speech discrimination.

 

Option D. Sensory presbycusis begins at the apex of the cochlea and affects low-frequency hearing first: Incorrect. Sensory presbycusis starts at the basal coil, affecting high-frequency hearing first, not the apex or low frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cochlear conductive presbycusis results from stiffening of the basilar membrane and is characterized by a sloping audiogram pattern.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 36

choices.text: The fast component of optokinetic nystagmus follows the direction of the moving stripes
The test is primarily used to diagnose peripheral vestibular dysfunction
Optokinetic nystagmus abnormalities suggest a lesion in the brainstem or cerebral hemisphere
The test involves tracking horizontal lines in a stationary field

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the optokinetic test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Optokinetic nystagmus abnormalities suggest a lesion in the brainstem or cerebral hemisphere

 

  • Optokinetic nystagmus abnormalities are seen in central nervous system disorders, including brainstem and cerebral hemisphere lesions. Therefore, this test is valuable in evaluating central vestibular pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The fast component of optokinetic nystagmus follows the direction of the moving stripes: Incorrect. In the optokinetic test, the slow component follows the direction of the moving stripes, while the fast component is in the opposite direction — this helps maintain fixation during visual tracking.

 

Option B. The test is primarily used to diagnose peripheral vestibular dysfunction: Incorrect. The optokinetic test is primarily used to detect central lesions, especially in the brainstem or cerebral hemispheres, not peripheral vestibular disorders.

 

Option D. The test involves tracking horizontal lines in a stationary field: Incorrect. The test involves tracking vertical stripes on a moving drum, not stationary lines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The optokinetic test helps identify central lesions, as abnormalities in optokinetic nystagmus indicate dysfunction in the brainstem or cerebral hemispheres.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 44

choices.text: Auditory faculty – Written language
Tactile faculty – Sound signal via cochlear implant
Visual faculty – Lip reading and sign language
Auditory faculty – Vibrotactile aid

questions.text: Based on the communication model for hearing-impaired individuals, which of the following pairs correctly matches a receptive faculty with its corresponding input modality?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Visual faculty – Lip reading and sign language

 

  • Lip reading, sign language, and written language are all received visually, making visual faculty a major input channel for receptive communication in the hearing impaired.

 

 

In hearing-impaired persons, communication skills—both receptive and expressive—can be developed by utilizing alternative sensory pathways such as vision, touch, and aided hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auditory faculty – Written language: Incorrect. Written language is processed through visual faculty, not auditory. Auditory faculty deals with sound signals, processed via hearing aids or cochlear implants.

 

Option B. Tactile faculty – Sound signal via cochlear implant: Incorrect. Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve, so this belongs under the auditory faculty, not tactile. The tactile faculty is used when sound is perceived through vibration, such as vibrotactile aids.

 

Option D. Auditory faculty – Vibrotactile aid: Incorrect. Vibrotactile aids are sensed through touch and belong to the tactile faculty, not auditory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hearing-impaired individuals, the visual faculty facilitates receptive skills like lip reading, sign language, and reading written language.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 120

choices.text: Craniofacial anomalies involving the ear or pinna
Mechanical ventilation for more than 5 days
Birth weight of more than 3000 g
Use of aminoglycosides in multiple courses

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for hearing loss in children as per the Joint Committee on Infant Hearing (1994) guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Birth weight of more than 3000 g

 

  • Low birth weight (specifically <1500 g) is considered a risk factor. A birth weight >3000 g is not associated with an increased risk and is considered normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniofacial anomalies involving the ear or pinna: Incorrect. This is a recognized risk factor, as structural abnormalities of the external ear often correlate with inner ear or auditory nerve anomalies.

 

Option B. Mechanical ventilation for more than 5 days: Incorrect. Prolonged mechanical ventilation (≥5 days) increases the risk of hearing loss due to associated hypoxia or ototoxic medications, making it a valid risk factor.

 

Option D. Use of aminoglycosides in multiple courses: Incorrect. Aminoglycosides, especially when used in multiple courses or in combination with loop diuretics, are ototoxic and listed as significant risk factors for hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with birth weight <1500 g, craniofacial anomalies, ototoxic drug exposure, or prolonged ventilation are at increased risk of hearing loss and should be screened early.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: It involves conditioning the child to respond to pure tones with a play activity
It is primarily used in neonates using non-verbal behavioral cues
It is not useful in assessing speech discrimination abilities
It involves asking the child to name or point to objects as the examiner's voice is gradually lowered

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Speech Audiometry in children is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It involves asking the child to name or point to objects as the examiner's voice is gradually lowered

 

  • In speech audiometry, the child is asked to repeat names of objects or point to pictures, and the voice level is gradually lowered to assess both hearing level and speech discrimination. It can also test expressive ability when the child names the object.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It involves conditioning the child to respond to pure tones with a play activity: Incorrect. This describes play audiometry, where a child performs an action like placing a block upon hearing a pure tone, not speech.

 

Option B. It is primarily used in neonates using non-verbal behavioral cues: 
Incorrect. Speech audiometry requires verbal interaction, so it is not suitable for neonates. Behavioral tests like OAE or ABR are used for neonates instead.

 

Option C. It is not useful in assessing speech discrimination abilities: Incorrect. In fact, speech audiometry is specifically designed to assess speech discrimination and hearing threshold using speech stimuli.

 

Educational Objective:


Speech audiometry in children evaluates hearing level and speech discrimination by asking them to name or identify objects as voice intensity is gradually reduced.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: SSNHL is defined as ≥30 dB loss at one frequency occurring over 7 days
Spontaneous recovery occurs in over 90% of idiopathic cases within 2 weeks
Intratympanic steroid therapy helps increase local steroid levels with fewer systemic side effects
The presence of vertigo is associated with a better prognosis in SSNHL

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSNHL) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intratympanic steroid therapy helps increase local steroid levels with fewer systemic side effects

 

  • Intratympanic steroids are used to increase the local steroid concentration in the cochlear fluids, and reduce systemic side effects, especially in patients who cannot tolerate oral steroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SSNHL is defined as ≥30 dB loss at one frequency occurring over 7 days: Incorrect. Sudden SNHL is defined as a ≥30 dB hearing loss across at least three contiguous frequencies, occurring in 3 days or less, not 7 days or one frequency.

 

Option B. Spontaneous recovery occurs in over 90% of idiopathic cases within 2 weeks: Incorrect. Spontaneous recovery occurs in about 50–60% of idiopathic SSNHL cases, typically within 15 days, not 90%.

 

Option D. The presence of vertigo is associated with a better prognosis in SSNHL: Incorrect. The presence of vertigo in SSNHL is a poor prognostic indicator, whereas younger age and moderate hearing loss are associated with better outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intratympanic steroid therapy in SSNHL improves cochlear drug delivery while minimizing systemic side effects, making it effective in selected patients.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 36

choices.text: No latency, non-fatiguable, direction changing
Latency of 2–20 seconds, duration less than 1 minute, direction fixed toward under ear
Latency absent, duration less than 30 seconds, direction changing
Direction of nystagmus changes with head position and is associated with no vertigo

questions.text: Which of the following features is most suggestive of positional nystagmus of peripheral origin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latency of 2–20 seconds, duration less than 1 minute, direction fixed toward under ear

 

  • These are classic features of peripheral positional nystagmus seen in conditions like benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Nystagmus is delayed (2–20 s), brief (<1 min), fatiguable, and always directed toward the undermost ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No latency, non-fatiguable, direction changing: Incorrect. These are typical features of central positional nystagmus, not peripheral. Central lesions present with immediate onset, non-fatiguable, and direction-changing nystagmus.

 

Option C. Latency absent, duration less than 30 seconds, direction changing: Incorrect. This option is inconsistent. While absent latency and direction-changing nystagmus point to a central cause, the short duration is more typical of peripheral causes, making this a mixed and incorrect option.

 

Option D. Direction of nystagmus changes with head position and is associated with no vertigo: Incorrect. Direction-changing nystagmus with minimal or no vertigo is suggestive of central pathology, not peripheral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripheral positional nystagmus is characterized by a latency of 2–20 seconds, short duration (<1 minute), fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and is fatiguable with severe vertigo.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 42

choices.text: EcoG is primarily used to measure brainstem auditory responses occurring after 10 ms
Summating potential to action potential (SP/AP) ratio above 30% is suggestive of Ménière’s disease
The recording electrode is placed on the scalp in all cases
Sedation interferes with the reliability of EcoG in children

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Electrocochleography (EcoG) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Summating potential to action potential (SP/AP) ratio above 30% is suggestive of Ménière’s disease

 

  • Normally, the SP/AP ratio is <30%, but a higher ratio is considered a diagnostic marker for Ménière’s disease, due to endolymphatic hydrops causing elevated summating potentials.

 

 

Electrocochleography:

 

(A) In a normal ear, the voltage of the summating potential (SP) is typically less than 30% of the action potential (AP).

 

(B) In Ménière’s disease, this SP/AP ratio is increased, indicating elevated summating potential relative to action potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EcoG is primarily used to measure brainstem auditory responses occurring after 10 ms: Incorrect. EcoG measures electrical potentials within the first 5 milliseconds, arising from the cochlea and VIII cranial nerve, not the brainstem. Responses after 10 ms are typically assessed in Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA).

 

Option C. The recording electrode is placed on the scalp in all cases: Incorrect. In EcoG, the recording electrode is a thin needle inserted through the tympanic membrane onto the promontory, not just placed on the scalp. This makes the test invasive but highly sensitive.

 

Option D. Sedation interferes with the reliability of EcoG in children: Incorrect. Sedation does not interfere with EcoG results. In fact, sedation or general anesthesia is often required in children or anxious patients to facilitate proper electrode placement and recording.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrocochleography detects inner ear and auditory nerve responses within 5 ms, and an SP/AP ratio >30% is suggestive of Ménière’s disease.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: VRA is best suited for children above 3 years of age
VRA involves conditioning the child to turn toward sound, reinforced by visual stimuli like flashing lights or animated toys
VRA uses only bone conduction testing as headphones are not well tolerated by infants
VRA cannot determine hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Visual Reinforcement Audiometry (VRA) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VRA involves conditioning the child to turn toward sound, reinforced by visual stimuli like flashing lights or animated toys

 

  • VRA is a conditioning technique where the child is trained to turn their head in response to an auditory stimulus, and this behavior is reinforced by flashing lights or animated toys, helping to determine hearing thresholds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VRA is best suited for children above 3 years of age: Incorrect. VRA is ideally suited for children in the developmental age of 6 months to 2 years, not above 3 years, where behavioral conditioning to auditory cues is more effective.
