Option C. VRA uses only bone conduction testing as headphones are not well tolerated by infants: Incorrect. VRA typically uses headphones or insert earphones, not exclusively bone conduction. Insert earphones are especially preferred in infants as they are lightweight and better tolerated.

 

Option D. VRA cannot determine hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques: Incorrect. One of the main uses of VRA is to determine hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques, making it highly valuable in early pediatric hearing assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual Reinforcement Audiometry (VRA) is used in children aged 6 months to 2 years to assess hearing by conditioning head-turning responses to sound, reinforced with visual stimuli.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: Manual communication is preferred over auditory-oral methods in post lingually deaf children
Vibrotactile aids are used to amplify sound in children with mild hearing loss
Total communication involves auditory, visual, tactile, and kinesthetic inputs to develop multiple communication modes
Hearing aids should be avoided in children with residual hearing to prevent auditory overload

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of hearing-impaired children is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total communication involves auditory, visual, tactile, and kinesthetic inputs to develop multiple communication modes

 

  • Total communication uses all available sensory inputs to teach communication—this includes oral speech, lipreading, sign language, and tactile inputs. It is especially beneficial in prelingually deaf children with severe-to-profound hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Manual communication is preferred over auditory-oral methods in postlingually deaf children: Incorrect. Auditory-oral communication is preferred for postlingually deaf or moderate to severe hearing loss cases. Manual methods (like sign language) are more often used in prelingual deafness or profound loss.

 

Option B. Vibrotactile aids are used to amplify sound in children with mild hearing loss: Incorrect. Vibrotactile aids are specifically designed for children who are both profoundly deaf and blind, not for mild hearing loss. They transmit sound vibrations through tactile means.

 

Option D. Hearing aids should be avoided in children with residual hearing to prevent auditory overload: Incorrect. Hearing aids should be prescribed as early as possible, especially in children with residual hearing, to amplify sound and support speech and language development. Avoiding aids would delay habilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total communication in hearing-impaired children involves using auditory, visual, tactile, and kinesthetic methods to promote comprehensive language development.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 120

choices.text: Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are absent in VIIIth nerve neuropathy
Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is considered normal in infants if response is seen at 60 dB nHL
OAEs may be absent due to middle ear effusion or canal debris in the first few days after birth
Arousal test is performed when the infant is fully awake and alert

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hearing assessment in infants is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OAEs may be absent due to middle ear effusion or canal debris in the first few days after birth

 

  • OAEs can be falsely absent in neonates due to canal debris (e.g., meconium) or middle ear effusion, which impede the reverse travel of sound energy, even when cochlear function is normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are absent in VIIIth nerve neuropathy: Incorrect. OAEs originate from outer hair cells in the cochlea and are preserved in VIIIth nerve neuropathy, since the cochlear function is intact despite nerve dysfunction.

 

Option B. Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is considered normal in infants if response is seen at 60 dB nHL: Incorrect. A normal ABR response in infants is typically seen at 30–35 dB nHL. Higher thresholds may suggest hearing loss.

 

Option D. Arousal test is performed when the infant is fully awake and alert: Incorrect. The arousal test is specifically done when the infant is in light sleep, and a normal hearing infant should arouse to sound stimuli at least twice out of three presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonates, OAEs may be absent due to middle ear effusion or canal debris despite normal cochlear function, highlighting the need for careful interpretation in early screening.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: Cotton wool
Ear plugs alone
Ear muffs alone
Combination of ear plugs and ear muffs

questions.text: Which of the following combinations provides the maximum hearing attenuation against environmental noise?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Combination of ear plugs and ear muffs

 

  • The combination of ear plugs and muffs provides the maximum attenuation—more than 40 dB, and covers a broader frequency range effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotton wool: Incorrect. Cotton wool provides minimal attenuation, about 5 dB, and is not sufficient for significant protection in noisy environments.

 

Option B. Ear plugs alone: Incorrect. Ear plugs provide attenuation of 15–30 dB, mostly effective in the 3–5 kHz range, but this is not the highest level of protection.

 

Option C. Ear muffs alone: Incorrect. Ear muffs offer better protection than ear plugs, with attenuation of 30–40 dB, especially in the 500–1000 Hz range, but still less than the combination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of ear plugs and ear muffs provides the highest level of noise attenuation, offering more than 40 dB of protection across a wide frequency range.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 34

choices.text: It is preferred over water caloric testing in patients with intact tympanic membranes
It uses warm air to stimulate the cochlear portion of the inner ear
It is contraindicated in tympanic membrane perforation
It is a qualitative vestibular test using cooled air through a Dundas Grant tube

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the cold-air caloric test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a qualitative vestibular test using cooled air through a Dundas Grant tube

 

  • The cold-air caloric test is a rough qualitative test of vestibular function, utilizing cooled air (typically via ethyl chloride cooling) delivered through a Dundas Grant tube in cases where water irrigation is contraindicated, such as TM perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is preferred over water caloric testing in patients with intact tympanic membranes: Incorrect. The cold-air caloric test is used specifically when the tympanic membrane is perforated, as water irrigation is contraindicated in such cases. In intact TMs, water caloric testing is more accurate.

 

Option B. It uses warm air to stimulate the cochlear portion of the inner ear: Incorrect. The test uses cold air, not warm air, and it assesses vestibular function, not cochlear. The Dundas Grant tube helps deliver cooled air to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal.

 

Option C. It is contraindicated in tympanic membrane perforation: Incorrect. In fact, this test is performed because there is a TM perforation — it's a safe alternative to avoid water entering the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cold-air caloric test is a qualitative vestibular test used when the tympanic membrane is perforated, utilizing cooled air delivered through a Dundas Grant tube.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 43

choices.text: Nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis typically beats toward the affected side
Nystagmus from central causes is suppressed by optic fixation
Vertical downbeat nystagmus suggests a lesion in the craniocervical region such as Arnold–Chiari malformation
Peripheral vestibular nystagmus is purely torsional and disconjugate

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vestibular nystagmus is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertical downbeat nystagmus suggests a lesion in the craniocervical region such as Arnold–Chiari malformation

 

  • Vertical downbeat nystagmus is a hallmark of craniocervical junction disorders, including Arnold–Chiari malformation or degenerative cerebellar disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis typically beats toward the affected side: Incorrect. Purulent labyrinthitis is a paretic lesion, which causes nystagmus to the healthy side, not the affected one. Irritative lesions (e.g., serous labyrinthitis) cause nystagmus toward the lesion.

 

Option B. Nystagmus from central causes is suppressed by optic fixation: 
Incorrect. Peripheral nystagmus can be suppressed by optic fixation, while central nystagmus cannot be suppressed, making this an important diagnostic distinction.

 

Option D. Peripheral vestibular nystagmus is purely torsional and disconjugate: Incorrect. Purely torsional or disconjugate nystagmus (e.g., vertical in one eye and horizontal in another) is typically central in origin, not peripheral. Peripheral nystagmus is usually horizontal-rotatory and conjugate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vertical downbeat nystagmus is characteristic of central vestibular pathology, particularly lesions at the craniocervical junction such as Arnold–Chiari malformation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 41

choices.text: The inner ear develops from endoderm near the first pharyngeal pouch
The saccule and cochlea (pars superior) develop earlier than the semicircular canals and utricle
The auditory placode gives rise to the otocyst, which forms the membranous labyrinth
Development of external, middle, and inner ear structures occurs simultaneously and symmetrically

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the development of the membranous inner ear is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The auditory placode gives rise to the otocyst, which forms the membranous labyrinth

 

  • During the 3rd week of gestation, the auditory placode invaginates to form the otocyst (auditory vesicle), which further differentiates into:
    • Endolymphatic duct and sac
    • Utricle and semicircular ducts (pars superior)
    • Saccule and cochlea (pars inferior)

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The inner ear develops from endoderm near the first pharyngeal pouch: Incorrect. The inner ear develops from ectoderm, specifically from a thickened region called the auditory placode near the hindbrain—not from endoderm.

 

Option B. The saccule and cochlea (pars superior) develop earlier than the semicircular canals and utricle: Incorrect. The semicircular canals and utricle represent the pars superior and develop earlier than the saccule and cochlea, which form the pars inferior.

 

Option D. Development of external, middle, and inner ear structures occurs simultaneously and symmetrically: Incorrect. The development of external, middle, and inner ears occurs independently, both in timing and embryologic origin, explaining why one part can be malformed while the others are normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The auditory placode forms the otocyst, which differentiates into the membranous labyrinth including endolymphatic structures, with pars superior (utricle and semicircular canals) developing earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 12.

choices.text: Endocochlear potential is an AC potential generated by hair cell movement during sound stimulation
Cochlear microphonic is a DC potential that does not require an external sound stimulus
Summating potential is a receptor potential that follows the envelope of the sound stimulus and may aid in diagnosing Ménière’s disease
Compound action potential is a graded potential with no latency and no refractory period

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cochlear and auditory nerve potentials is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Summating potential is a receptor potential that follows the envelope of the sound stimulus and may aid in diagnosing Ménière’s disease

 

  • Summating potential (SP) is a DC receptor potential generated by hair cells. It follows the envelope of the stimulus and can be positive or negative. Abnormally increased SP is useful in electrocochleography for diagnosing Ménière’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endocochlear potential is an AC potential generated by hair cell movement during sound stimulation: Incorrect. Endocochlear potential is a DC potential of +80 mV generated by the stria vascularis in the scala media, independent of sound. It acts as a battery driving current during hair cell deflection.

 

Option B. Cochlear microphonic is a DC potential that does not require an external sound stimulus: Incorrect. Cochlear microphonic (CM) is an AC potential generated by hair cell depolarization when the basilar membrane moves in response to sound. It is not present at rest.

 

Option D. Compound action potential is a graded potential with no latency and no refractory period: Incorrect. Compound action potential is an all-or-none response from auditory nerve fibers, unlike receptor potentials. It has latency, is propagated, and shows a refractory period, all characteristics of true nerve action potentials.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The summating potential is a DC receptor potential generated by hair cells, follows the sound envelope, and is useful in diagnosing Ménière’s disease.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13

choices.text: Vestibular nuclei receive afferents only from the peripheral vestibular apparatus
Efferents from vestibular nuclei to cranial nerves III, IV, VI mediate auditory reflexes
Vestibulospinal fibres help maintain posture by coordinating head, neck, and body movements
Subjective awareness of motion is mediated via projections to the occipital cortex

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding central vestibular connections is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vestibulospinal fibres help maintain posture by coordinating head, neck, and body movements

 

  • Efferent fibres from vestibular nuclei descend via the vestibulospinal tract to the motor neurons of the spinal cord, helping coordinate movements of head, neck, and trunk to maintain postural balance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vestibular nuclei receive afferents only from the peripheral vestibular apparatus: Incorrect. While semicircular canals, utricle, and saccule send input to vestibular nuclei, they also receive afferents from the cerebellum, reticular formation, spinal cord, and contralateral vestibular nuclei. Thus, they integrate multiple sensory systems for balance.

 

Option B Efferents from vestibular nuclei to cranial nerves III, IV, VI mediate auditory reflexes: Incorrect. Efferents from vestibular nuclei to these cranial nerves via the medial longitudinal bundle (MLF) mediate the vestibulo-ocular reflex, not auditory reflexes. This connection is responsible for nystagmus during vestibular stimulation.

 

Option D. Subjective awareness of motion is mediated via projections to the occipital cortex: Incorrect. The temporal lobe (not occipital) is responsible for subjective awareness of motion through vestibulocortical connections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vestibulospinal fibres from the vestibular nuclei coordinate head, neck, and body movements to maintain posture and balance.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 17

choices.text: Stimulation of the posterior semicircular canal results in horizontal nystagmus
Ampullopetal flow is less effective than ampullofugal flow in the horizontal canal
Nystagmus is always in the same direction as endolymph flow in the semicircular canals
Semicircular canals detect angular acceleration, while utricle and saccule respond to linear acceleration and gravity

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the vestibular system and semicircular canals is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Semicircular canals detect angular acceleration, while utricle and saccule respond to linear acceleration and gravity

 

The semicircular canals are specialized for detecting angular acceleration/deceleration, while the utricle and saccule (otolith organs) detect linear acceleration, head tilt, and gravitational forces. This combination allows precise detection of head movements in all planes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulation of the posterior semicircular canal results in horizontal nystagmus: Incorrect. The posterior semicircular canal causes vertical nystagmus when stimulated. It’s the horizontal canal that causes horizontal nystagmus, and the superior canal causes rotatory nystagmus.

 

Option B. Ampullopetal flow is less effective than ampullofugal flow in the horizontal canal: Incorrect. In the horizontal canal, ampullopetal flow (toward the cupula) is more effective than ampullofugal (away from the cupula) in stimulating hair cells.

 

Option C. Nystagmus is always in the same direction as endolymph flow in the semicircular canals: Incorrect. The quick component of nystagmus is opposite to the direction of endolymph flow. For example, if endolymph moves to the right, the nystagmus is to the left.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Semicircular canals detect angular acceleration, while the utricle and saccule respond to linear acceleration, head tilt, and gravitational forces for maintaining equilibrium.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 17

choices.text: Cristae in the semicircular ducts respond to linear acceleration and head tilt
Macula of the utricle lies vertically and responds to angular acceleration
Otolithic membrane contains calcium carbonate crystals and helps detect gravity and linear motion
Scarpa’s ganglion contains multipolar neurons and lies in the medial part of the internal auditory canal

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the vestibular system is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otolithic membrane contains calcium carbonate crystals and helps detect gravity and linear motion

 

  • The maculae (in utricle and saccule) have a gelatinous otolithic membrane embedded with calcium carbonate crystals called otoliths or otoconia. These respond to gravity, linear acceleration, and head tilt by bending the cilia of underlying hair cells.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cristae in the semicircular ducts respond to linear acceleration and head tilt: Incorrect. Cristae are located in the ampullae of semicircular ducts and are sensitive to angular acceleration (rotational movements), not linear motion or tilt.

 

 

Option B. Macula of the utricle lies vertically and responds to angular acceleration: Incorrect. The macula of the utricle lies in a horizontal plane, not vertical. It senses head position relative to gravity and linear acceleration, not angular acceleration.

 

 

Option D. Scarpa’s ganglion contains multipolar neurons and lies in the medial part of the internal auditory canal: Incorrect. Scarpa’s ganglion (vestibular ganglion) is located in the lateral part of the internal acoustic meatus and contains bipolar neurons, not multipolar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The otolithic membrane in the macula contains calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) that respond to gravity and linear acceleration by stimulating the underlying hair cells.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 16

choices.text: Pinna
External auditory meatus
Cochlea
Middle ear

questions.text: Based on the development timeline of ear structures, which of the following completes its development latest during fetal life?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Middle ear

 

 

From the chart:

  • Pinna:
    • Begins: 6th week
    • Completes: 20th week
  • Meatus (External auditory canal):
    • Begins: 8th week
    • Completes: 28th week
  • Middle ear:
    • Begins: 3rd week
    • Completes: 30th week 
  • Vestibular labyrinth:
    • Begins: 3rd week
    • Completes: 20th week
  • Cochlea:
    • Begins: 3rd week
    • Completes: 20th week

 

Hence, the middle ear is the last among these structures to complete development, finishing at the 30th week of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the ear structures, the middle ear completes its development last—by the 30th week of gestation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 12

choices.text: Spiral ganglion is located in the modiolus of the cochlea and contains multipolar neurons
The auditory cortex is located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann area 4)
Each ear is represented only in the contralateral cerebral hemisphere
The axons of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion form the cochlear nerve and terminate in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the auditory neural pathway is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The axons of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion form the cochlear nerve and terminate in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei

 

  • Hair cells synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion. Their axons form the cochlear division of CN VIII, which terminates in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei of the medulla.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiral ganglion is located in the modiolus of the cochlea and contains multipolar neurons: Incorrect. The spiral ganglion lies in Rosenthal’s canal, which runs along the osseous spiral lamina (not in the modiolus), and contains bipolar (not multipolar) neurons.

 

 

Option B. The auditory cortex is located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann area 4): Incorrect. The auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann’s area 41, not area 4 (which is the primary motor cortex in the precentral gyrus).

 

 

Option C. Each ear is represented only in the contralateral cerebral hemisphere: Incorrect. Due to multiple decussations in the central auditory pathway, each ear is represented bilaterally in both cerebral hemispheres.

 

Mnemonic:

 

E. COLI-MA

 

  • E – Eighth nerve
  • C – Cochlear nuclei
  • O – Olivary complex
  • L – Lateral lemniscus
  • I – Inferior colliculus
  • M – Medial geniculate body
  • A – Auditory cortex

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cochlear nerve arises from bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion and projects to the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei, with the auditory pathway ascending bilaterally through E. COLI-MA to the auditory cortex in Brodmann area 41.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13.

choices.text: Outer hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory impulses via afferent fibers
Inner hair cells are arranged in multiple rows and receive efferent innervation from the olivary complex
The shearing movement between the tectorial membrane and hair cells stimulates auditory transduction
Deiters’ cells support inner hair cells and lie medial to the tunnel of Corti

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Organ of Corti is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The shearing movement between the tectorial membrane and hair cells stimulates auditory transduction

 

  • The tectorial membrane lies over the hair cells of the Organ of Corti. The relative movement (shearing force) between the tectorial membrane and stereocilia of hair cells during sound vibration triggers electrical signals that are sent to the brain.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outer hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory impulses via afferent fibers: Incorrect. Outer hair cells mainly receive efferent innervation from the olivary complex and are involved in modulating the response of inner hair cells, not in primary transmission.

 

 

Option B. Inner hair cells are arranged in multiple rows and receive efferent innervation from the olivary complex: Incorrect. Inner hair cells form a single row, are richly innervated by afferent fibers, and are primarily responsible for the transmission of auditory signals.

 

 

Option D. Deiters’ cells support inner hair cells and lie medial to the tunnel of Corti: Incorrect. Deiters’ cells support outer hair cells, not inner ones, and are located between them. Hensen’s cells lie lateral to Deiters’ cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The shearing force between the tectorial membrane and hair cells in the Organ of Corti is responsible for initiating auditory transduction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13

choices.text: Both the bony and membranous labyrinth are filled with perilymph
The membranous labyrinth is filled with perilymph and lies within the endolymph-filled bony labyrinth
The membranous labyrinth is filled with endolymph, and the space between it and the bony labyrinth contains perilymph
The bony labyrinth is filled with endolymph and surrounds the perilymph-filled membranous labyrinth

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the fluid compartments of the internal ear (labyrinth)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The membranous labyrinth is filled with endolymph, and the space between it and the bony labyrinth contains perilymph

 

  • The internal ear is composed of:
    • A bony labyrinth: a rigid outer wall
    • A membranous labyrinth: lies within the bony labyrinth
    • Endolymph fills the membranous labyrinth
    • Perilymph occupies the space between the membranous and bony labyrinths

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both the bony and membranous labyrinth are filled with perilymph: Incorrect. Only the space between the bony and membranous labyrinth contains perilymph; the membranous labyrinth itself contains endolymph.

 

Option B. The membranous labyrinth is filled with perilymph and lies within the endolymph-filled bony labyrinth: Incorrect. The membranous labyrinth is filled with endolymph, not perilymph.

 

Option D. The bony labyrinth is filled with endolymph and surrounds the perilymph-filled membranous labyrinth: Incorrect. The bony labyrinth contains perilymph; endolymph is restricted to the membranous labyrinth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The membranous labyrinth of the internal ear contains endolymph, while the space between it and the surrounding bony labyrinth contains perilymph.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 9

choices.text: Scala media is filled with perilymph and communicates with scala tympani via helicotrema
The utricle is located anterior to the saccule and receives input from the ductus reuniens
The basilar membrane is widest at the base, hence low-frequency sounds are heard there
Endolymphatic sac lies between layers of dura and is a surgical target in Ménière’s disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the internal ear is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endolymphatic sac lies between layers of dura and is a surgical target in Ménière’s disease

 

  • The endolymphatic sac, formed by the endolymphatic duct, lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone. It is surgically accessed for drainage or shunt procedures in Ménière’s disease, where endolymphatic hydrops (distension) is present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scala media is filled with perilymph and communicates with scala tympani via helicotrema: Incorrect. The scala media (cochlear duct) is part of the membranous labyrinth and is filled with endolymph, not perilymph. Scala vestibuli and scala tympani are the perilymph-filled compartments that communicate through the helicotrema at the cochlear apex.

 

 

Option B. The utricle is located anterior to the saccule and receives input from the ductus reuniens: Incorrect. The utricle lies posterior to the saccule and receives the semicircular ducts. The saccule connects to the cochlear duct via the ductus reuniens.

 

 

Option C. The basilar membrane is widest at the base, hence low-frequency sounds are heard there: Incorrect. The basilar membrane becomes wider toward the apex of the cochlea. High-frequency sounds are detected at the base, while low-frequency sounds are detected at the apex due to membrane properties.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The endolymphatic sac lies between layers of dura on the petrous bone and is surgically accessed in Ménière’s disease for decompression or shunting. Openings and lodges both the saccule and utricle.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 9.

choices.text: It is used to evaluate only the vestibular component of balance control
It relies on altering visual, vestibular, and somatosensory inputs to assess postural stability
It provides definitive diagnosis of vestibular disorders
Posturography must be performed with a moving platform only

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding posturography is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It relies on altering visual, vestibular, and somatosensory inputs to assess postural stability

 

  • Posturography is based on the principle that postural control is maintained by integration of visual, vestibular, and proprioceptive (somatosensory) inputs. It uses variations in these cues (like changing the platform or visual field) to assess balance strategy and deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is used to evaluate only the vestibular component of balance control: Incorrect. Posturography evaluates all three systems that contribute to balance: visual, vestibular, and somatosensory. It is not limited to the vestibular component.

 

Option C. It provides definitive diagnosis of vestibular disorders: Incorrect. While posturography can assess balance, it does not provide a definitive diagnosis of vestibular disorders. Its clinical application is still under investigation.

 

Option D. Posturography must be performed with a moving platform only: Incorrect. Posturography can be performed using either a fixed or a moving platform. The choice depends on the type of balance assessment required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posturography assesses postural stability by evaluating the integration of visual, vestibular, and somatosensory inputs through fixed or moving platforms.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 44

choices.text: BPPV is commonly associated with persistent hearing loss and tinnitus
The Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre is used to treat BPPV by dislodging otoconia from the semicircular canal
Epley’s manoeuvre repositions otoconial debris from the posterior semicircular canal into the utricle
Vertigo in BPPV is non-fatiguable and gets worse with repeated testing

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epley’s manoeuvre repositions otoconial debris from the posterior semicircular canal into the utricle

 

Epley’s manoeuvre repositions otoconial debris into the utricle: Correct. The Epley’s manoeuvre is a repositioning technique that moves free-floating otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) from the posterior semicircular canal back into the utricle, relieving vertigo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BPPV is commonly associated with persistent hearing loss and tinnitus: Incorrect. BPPV typically presents with positional vertigo only, without hearing loss or other neurologic symptoms. Hearing loss suggests a different vestibular pathology.

 

Option B. The Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre is used to treat BPPV by dislodging otoconia from the semicircular canal: Incorrect. The Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre is used for diagnosis, not treatment. It helps elicit nystagmus and vertigo in the affected position.

 

 

Option D. Vertigo in BPPV is non-fatiguable and gets worse with repeated testing: Incorrect. BPPV-related vertigo is fatiguable — meaning it reduces or disappears with repeated positioning due to dispersion of otoconia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epley’s manoeuvre treats BPPV by repositioning otoconial debris from the posterior semicircular canal back into the utricle.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 45

choices.text: Sudden-onset vertigo associated with tinnitus and hearing loss
Self-limiting vertigo episodes that last from a few seconds to minutes
Severe vertigo without cochlear symptoms, lasting days to weeks
Progressive hearing loss with episodic vertigo due to endolymphatic hydrops

questions.text: Which of the following features is most characteristic of vestibular neuronitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe vertigo without cochlear symptoms, lasting days to weeks

 

  • Vestibular neuronitis presents with sudden, severe vertigo that may last for days to weeks, with no associated hearing loss or tinnitus. It is believed to be viral in origin, affecting the vestibular ganglion, and is typically self-limiting.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sudden-onset vertigo associated with tinnitus and hearing loss: Incorrect. These features suggest Ménière’s disease, which involves both cochlear (hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular (vertigo) symptoms.

 

Option B. Self-limiting vertigo episodes that last from a few seconds to minutes: Incorrect. Such short-lasting episodes are more typical of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), not vestibular neuronitis.

 

Option D. Progressive hearing loss with episodic vertigo due to endolymphatic hydrops: Incorrect. This describes Ménière’s disease, not vestibular neuronitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vestibular neuronitis presents as sudden-onset, prolonged vertigo without cochlear symptoms and is believed to be due to a viral vestibular ganglionitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 45

choices.text: Serous labyrinthitis results in irreversible destruction of cochlear and vestibular function
Circumscribed labyrinthitis is typically seen in safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media
Purulent labyrinthitis causes vertigo due to acute vestibular failure with nystagmus toward the affected side
In circumscribed labyrinthitis, a positive fistula test is usually present due to erosion of the bony labyrinth

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding labyrinthitis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In circumscribed labyrinthitis, a positive fistula test is usually present due to erosion of the bony labyrinth

 

  • Circumscribed labyrinthitis is due to localized bony erosion, typically from unsafe CSOM, leading to a positive fistula test, which confirms abnormal communication between middle and inner ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous labyrinthitis results in irreversible destruction of cochlear and vestibular function: Incorrect. In serous labyrinthitis, there is no actual invasion of the inner ear. With early treatment, partial or full recovery of inner ear function is possible.

 

Option B. Circumscribed labyrinthitis is typically seen in safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media: Incorrect. Circumscribed labyrinthitis is typically seen in the unsafe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), such as those with cholesteatoma, which can erode the bony labyrinth.

 

Option C. Purulent labyrinthitis causes vertigo due to acute vestibular failure with nystagmus toward the affected side: Incorrect. In purulent labyrinthitis, due to destruction of the labyrinth, nystagmus beats to the opposite side (i.e., the healthy side) because of vestibular hypofunction on the affected side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumscribed labyrinthitis is commonly seen in unsafe CSOM and is characterized by a positive fistula test due to localized erosion of the bony labyrinth.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 45

choices.text: Streptomycin and gentamicin damage primarily cochlear hair cells
Metronidazole and nalidixic acid may cause dizziness through vestibular hair cell destruction
Aminoglycosides like streptomycin primarily damage hair cells of the crista ampullaris
Vestibular sedatives commonly damage the macula of the utricle

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding vestibulotoxic drugs is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aminoglycosides like streptomycin primarily damage hair cells of the crista ampullaris

 

  • Streptomycin, gentamicin, and tobramycin (GST) are known to damage the vestibular sensory epithelium, especially hair cells of the crista ampullaris (in semicircular canals) and, to a lesser extent, the maculae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptomycin and gentamicin damage primarily cochlear hair cells:
Incorrect. While some aminoglycosides are cochleotoxic, streptomycin and gentamicin are more vestibulotoxic, affecting the crista ampullaris.

 

Option B. Metronidazole and nalidixic acid may cause dizziness through vestibular hair cell destruction: Incorrect. These drugs may cause dizziness or unsteadiness, but not necessarily by directly damaging vestibular hair cells. Their mechanism may differ, possibly involving central or systemic effects.

 

Option D. Vestibular sedatives commonly damage the macula of the utricle: Incorrect. Vestibular sedatives may cause unsteadiness through CNS depression, not by damaging inner ear hair cells like aminoglycosides do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminoglycosides like streptomycin exert vestibulotoxic effects by damaging the hair cells of the crista ampullaris in the vestibular labyrinth.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 45

choices.text: Vertigo in VBI is usually prolonged and accompanied by sensorineural hearing loss
VBI is typically seen in young patients and results from labyrinthine dysfunction
Cervical osteophytes can precipitate vertigo by compressing vertebral arteries during neck movements
Vertigo in VBI is always isolated and never associated with other neurological symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vertebrobasilar insufficiency (VBI) as a central vestibular disorder is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical osteophytes can precipitate vertigo by compressing vertebral arteries during neck movements

 

  • In VBI, rotation or extension of the neck can cause mechanical compression of vertebral arteries by cervical osteophytes, precipitating transient ischaemia and vertigo.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vertigo in VBI is usually prolonged and accompanied by sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. In VBI, vertigo is transient, usually lasting several minutes, and is not associated with hearing loss, which suggests a peripheral cause.

 

Option B. VBI is typically seen in young patients and results from labyrinthine dysfunction: Incorrect. VBI is a central cause of vertigo, seen commonly in older individuals (age >50) due to atherosclerosis, not labyrinthine (peripheral) causes.

 

Option D. Vertigo in VBI is always isolated and never associated with other neurological symptoms:  Incorrect. VBI is central in origin and often accompanied by other neurological signs like diplopia, hemiparesis, dysphagia, hemianopia, etc., due to brainstem and occipital lobe ischaemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In vertebrobasilar insufficiency, cervical osteophytes may compress vertebral arteries during head rotation or extension, leading to transient vertigo and associated brainstem symptoms.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 46

choices.text: Bilateral facial sensory loss and hemiparesis on the same side
Vertigo with ipsilateral Horner syndrome and contralateral body sensory loss
Hearing loss and facial palsy due to pontine infarct
Pure motor stroke with no cranial nerve involvement

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of posteroinferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertigo with ipsilateral Horner syndrome and contralateral body sensory loss

 

  • Wallenberg syndrome results from PICA thrombosis, affecting the lateral medulla, causing:
    • Vertigo, nystagmus (due to vestibular nuclei involvement)
    • Ipsilateral Horner syndrome (sympathetic tract)
    • Ipsilateral facial sensory loss (trigeminal nucleus)
    • Contralateral body pain/temp loss (spinothalamic tract)
    • Dysphagia, hoarseness (nucleus ambiguus involvement)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral facial sensory loss and hemiparesis on the same side: 
Incorrect. Wallenberg syndrome causes ipsilateral facial sensory loss (trigeminal tract) and contralateral body sensory loss (spinothalamic tract). Bilateral symptoms are not typical.

 

Option C. Hearing loss and facial palsy due to pontine infarct: Incorrect. These findings are more typical of AICA infarct or pontine syndromes, not Wallenberg/PICA infarct.

 

Option D. Pure motor stroke with no cranial nerve involvement: Incorrect. Wallenberg is a mixed cranial nerve and sensory stroke, not a pure motor stroke (which suggests internal capsule or cortical infarcts).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wallenberg syndrome (PICA infarct) presents with vertigo, ipsilateral Horner syndrome and facial sensory loss, contralateral body sensory loss, and bulbar symptoms like dysphagia and hoarseness.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 46

choices.text: Unilateral throbbing headache with sensorineural hearing loss
Recurrent occipital headache with vertigo, diplopia, and visual disturbances in adolescent girls
Persistent hemiparesis with retro-orbital pain in elderly males
Frontal headache associated with nasal congestion and photophobia

questions.text: Which of the following features is most characteristic of basilar migraine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent occipital headache with vertigo, diplopia, and visual disturbances in adolescent girls

 

  • Basilar migraine (also called migraine with brainstem aura) typically occurs in adolescent girls, has a strong menstrual and familial link, and is marked by occipital headache, visual aura, diplopia, and severe vertigo lasting 5–60 minutes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unilateral throbbing headache with sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. While migraine may present with unilateral throbbing headache, sensorineural hearing loss is not a feature of basilar migraine, and this option better describes vestibulocochlear pathology.

 

Option C. Persistent hemiparesis with retro-orbital pain in elderly males: Incorrect. This describes more likely a stroke or carotid dissection, not basilar migraine, which is transient and usually in younger females.

 

Option D. Frontal headache associated with nasal congestion and photophobia: Incorrect. This is characteristic of sinusitis, not basilar migraine. Migraine is vascular, not infective or inflammatory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basilar migraine presents with recurrent occipital headache, vertigo, diplopia, and visual disturbances, especially in adolescent girls with a positive menstrual and family history.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 46

choices.text: It presents immediately after neck injury and is usually associated with sensorineural hearing loss
It is aggravated by neck movements and may appear days after cervical trauma
It results from demyelination of cervical spinal cord and always has neurological deficits
Diagnosis is confirmed by caloric testing and pure tone audiometry

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cervical vertigo is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is aggravated by neck movements and may appear days after cervical trauma

 

  • Cervical vertigo is a post-traumatic condition that appears a few days after neck injury and is provoked by head/neck movement, especially to the side of injury. Examination may reveal neck tenderness, muscle spasm, and reduced cervical movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It presents immediately after neck injury and is usually associated with sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. Cervical vertigo typically presents 7–10 days after neck injury, and it is not associated with cochlear symptoms like hearing loss.

 

Option C. It results from demyelination of cervical spinal cord and always has neurological deficits: Incorrect. Though the exact mechanism of cervical vertigo is unclear, it is not typically due to demyelination. Theories include vertebrobasilar insufficiency, sympathetic plexus irritation, or tonic neck reflex alterations, but frank neurological signs are not always present.

 

Option D. Diagnosis is confirmed by caloric testing and pure tone audiometry:  Incorrect. These tests evaluate labyrinthine and cochlear function but are not useful for diagnosing cervical vertigo, which is related to neck movement and cervical spine pathology, often seen on X-ray as loss of cervical lordosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical vertigo is a delayed-onset vertigo occurring after neck injury, often triggered by neck movement and associated with cervical muscle spasm and tenderness.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 47

choices.text: Vertigo, conductive hearing loss, otalgia, and ear discharge
Vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness
Positional vertigo, normal hearing, and no tinnitus
Episodic vertigo with immediate resolution, no hearing involvement

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic combination of features in Ménière’s disease (endolymphatic hydrops)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness

 

  • This is the classic tetrad of Ménière’s disease, caused by distension of the endolymphatic system (endolymphatic hydrops), particularly affecting the cochlear duct, saccule, and utricle. Pathologically, Reissner’s membrane bulges, and scala media may herniate, leading to these characteristic symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vertigo, conductive hearing loss, otalgia, and ear discharge: Incorrect. This combination is typical of middle ear disorders like CSOM, not Ménière’s disease, which involves the inner ear and presents with sensorineural, not conductive hearing loss.

 

Option C. Positional vertigo, normal hearing, and no tinnitus: Incorrect. This pattern is typical of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), not Ménière’s disease. BPPV does not cause hearing loss or tinnitus.

 

Option D. Episodic vertigo with immediate resolution, no hearing involvement: Incorrect. While Ménière’s disease has episodic vertigo, it is always associated with fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ménière’s disease is characterized by episodic vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness due to endolymphatic hydrops in the inner ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 100

choices.text: Excessive perilymph production by the cochlear aqueduct
Defective absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac
Overstimulation of semicircular canals due to otoconia
Hypersecretion of endolymph by the perilymphatic sac

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is most commonly implicated in the pathogenesis of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac

 

  • The most accepted theory for Ménière’s disease is defective absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac, leading to distension (hydrops) of the membranous labyrinth. Experimental obstruction of the sac and duct also leads to similar findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive perilymph production by the cochlear aqueduct: Incorrect. Perilymph is not the main fluid involved in Ménière’s disease. The pathology lies in the endolymphatic system, not perilymph production.

 

Option C. Overstimulation of semicircular canals due to otoconia: Incorrect. This describes BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo), not Ménière’s disease. Otoconia are not involved in Ménière’s pathology.

 

Option D. Hypersecretion of endolymph by the perilymphatic sac: Incorrect. Endolymph is secreted by the stria vascularis, not the perilymphatic sac, and there is no such structure as a “perilymphatic sac.”

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accepted cause of Ménière’s disease is defective absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac, leading to endolymphatic hydrops and the classical triad of vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 100

choices.text: Persistent high-frequency hearing loss with purulent ear discharge
Episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness
Continuous rotational vertigo with bilateral conductive hearing loss
Vertigo worsened by change in head position with normal hearing

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness

 

  • This is the classical tetrad of Ménière’s disease, caused by endolymphatic hydrops. Vertigo is often sudden, rotatory, associated with nausea/vomiting, and may show Tullio phenomenon. Hearing loss is fluctuating, and tinnitus is typically low-pitched and roaring. A sense of ear fullness often precedes attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Persistent high-frequency hearing loss with purulent ear discharge: Incorrect. This suggests chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), not Ménière’s disease. Ménière’s is an inner ear disorder, typically with sensorineural (not conductive) hearing loss and no discharge.

 

Option C. Continuous rotational vertigo with bilateral conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. Ménière’s has episodic, not continuous vertigo, and the hearing loss is sensorineural, usually unilateral early on.

 

Option D. Vertigo worsened by change in head position with normal hearing: Incorrect. This is characteristic of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), not Ménière’s disease. In BPPV, hearing is typically normal, and vertigo is position-triggered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ménière’s disease typically presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, low-pitched tinnitus, and aural fullness due to endolymphatic hydrops.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 100

choices.text: SISI score less than 15% and negative recruitment test
Conductive hearing loss with a downward-sloping audiogram
Sensorineural hearing loss with rising audiogram in early stages and SP/AP ratio >30% on electrocochleography
Persistent spontaneous nystagmus toward the affected ear with reduced bone conduction

questions.text: Which of the following investigative findings is most characteristic of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensorineural hearing loss with rising audiogram in early stages and SP/AP ratio >30% on electrocochleography

 

  • Ménière’s disease typically shows:
    • Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, initially involving low frequencies
    • Positive electrocochleography with SP/AP ratio >30%
    • Positive glycerol test with audiometric improvement
  • These findings are highly suggestive of endolymphatic hydrops.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SISI score less than 15% and negative recruitment test: Incorrect. These findings are more consistent with retrocochlear lesions like acoustic neuroma. In Ménière’s disease, SISI is typically >70%, and recruitment is positive (suggesting cochlear involvement).

 

Option B. Conductive hearing loss with a downward-sloping audiogram: Incorrect. Ménière’s disease causes sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive. In early stages, low frequencies are affected, producing a rising audiometric curve.

 

Option D. Persistent spontaneous nystagmus toward the affected ear with reduced bone conduction: Incorrect. In Ménière’s disease, nystagmus beats toward the healthy side, and bone conduction is reduced due to SNHL, not persistently visible outside of an attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Ménière’s disease, early audiometry shows low-frequency SNHL (rising curve) and electrocochleography reveals an SP/AP ratio >30%, supporting the diagnosis of endolymphatic hydrops.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 100

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss with SISI score >70%, normal BERA, and preserved stapedial reflex
Sensorineural hearing loss with absent recruitment, tone decay >25 dB, and delayed wave V in BERA
Sensorineural hearing loss with recruitment present, SISI score >70%, and normal stapedial reflex
Normal hearing, speech discrimination score 95%, and BERA showing normal wave I-V interval

questions.text: Which of the following test findings best supports a diagnosis of a retrocochlear lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sensorineural hearing loss with absent recruitment, tone decay >25 dB, and delayed wave V in BERA

 

  • This triad is typical of retrocochlear lesions (e.g., vestibular schwannoma), where:
    • Recruitment is absent
    • Tone decay >25 dB is seen (indicating nerve fatigue)
    • Wave V in BERA is delayed or absent

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensorineural hearing loss with SISI score >70%, normal BERA, and preserved stapedial reflex: These features point toward a cochlear lesion, not retrocochlear. High SISI, recruitment, and normal BERA are classic for cochlear pathology (e.g., Ménière’s disease).

 

Option C. Sensorineural hearing loss with recruitment present, SISI score >70%, and normal stapedial reflex: This combination again fits cochlear lesion, not retrocochlear. Retrocochlear lesions lack recruitment and have poor SISI.

 

Option D. Normal hearing, speech discrimination score 95%, and BERA showing normal wave I-V interval: This fits a normal subject and does not indicate any lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A retrocochlear lesion is characterized by absent recruitment, poor SISI (<20%), tone decay >25 dB, and delayed or absent wave V in BERA.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 102

choices.text: Vestibular hydrops is characterized by recurrent hearing loss without vertigo
In drop attacks (Tumarkin's crisis), patients experience vertigo followed by unconsciousness
Lermoyez syndrome presents with hearing deterioration followed by vertigo with improvement in hearing
Cochlear hydrops is associated with episodic vertigo and normal hearing throughout

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes a variant of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lermoyez syndrome presents with hearing deterioration followed by vertigo with improvement in hearing

 

  • In Lermoyez syndrome, progressive hearing loss precedes vertigo, and notably, hearing improves after the vertigo episode — a reverse pattern compared to classical Ménière’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vestibular hydrops is characterized by recurrent hearing loss without vertigo: Incorrect. Vestibular hydrops presents with episodic vertigo while cochlear (hearing) functions are normal. Hearing loss is absent initially.

 

Option B. In drop attacks (Tumarkin's crisis), patients experience vertigo followed by unconsciousness: Incorrect. In Tumarkin's crisis, there is a sudden fall without loss of consciousness or vertigo. The patient feels as if pushed to the ground. It is due to otolithic dysfunction (utricle/saccule).

 

Option D. Cochlear hydrops is associated with episodic vertigo and normal hearing throughout: Incorrect. In cochlear hydrops, there is fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss without vertigo in the early stage. Vertigo may develop years later.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lermoyez syndrome is a variant of Ménière’s disease where hearing loss precedes vertigo, and hearing improves following the vertigo attack.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 102

choices.text: Ménière’s disease is always bilateral, while the syndrome is unilateral
Ménière’s syndrome is idiopathic, while Ménière’s disease has a known cause
Ménière’s disease is idiopathic, while Ménière’s syndrome is secondary to an identifiable cause
Both are caused by trauma but differ in severity of vertigo

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates Ménière’s disease from Ménière’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ménière’s disease is idiopathic, while Ménière’s syndrome is secondary to an identifiable cause

 

  • This is the key distinction:
    • Ménière’s disease: Primary/idiopathic condition with the classical triad of vertigo, fluctuating SNHL, and tinnitus with ear fullness.
    • Ménière’s syndrome: Similar clinical features but with a known underlying etiology, hence called secondary Ménière’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ménière’s disease is always bilateral, while the syndrome is unilateral: Incorrect. Ménière’s disease is often unilateral, especially in early stages. Bilaterality may develop later. The difference is not in laterality.

 

Option B. Ménière’s syndrome is idiopathic, while Ménière’s disease has a known cause: Incorrect reversal. Ménière’s disease is idiopathic, meaning no identifiable underlying cause. Ménière’s syndrome (also called secondary Ménière’s) occurs due to known conditions like trauma, viral infections, syphilis, autoimmune diseases, or otosclerosis.

 

Option D. Both are caused by trauma but differ in severity of vertigo: Incorrect. Ménière’s syndrome may be caused by trauma, but Ménière’s disease is not. Moreover, trauma is only one of many possible causes of the syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ménière’s disease is idiopathic, while Ménière’s syndrome refers to similar clinical features arising from identifiable causes such as trauma, infection, or autoimmune conditions.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 102

choices.text: One episode of vertigo with audiometrically confirmed hearing loss and tinnitus
Two or more episodes of vertigo lasting more than 20 minutes, hearing loss on audiometry, tinnitus or fullness, and exclusion of other causes
Histopathological confirmation of endolymphatic hydrops
Episodic vertigo with no documented hearing loss

questions.text: According to the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery (AAOHNS), which of the following criteria best defines a "Definite" diagnosis of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Two or more episodes of vertigo lasting more than 20 minutes, hearing loss on audiometry, tinnitus or fullness, and exclusion of other causes

 

  • This is the AAOHNS definition of "Definite Ménière’s disease". Key components:
    • ≥2 spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting ≥20 minutes
    • Audiometrically confirmed SNHL
    • Tinnitus or aural fullness
    • Exclusion of other causes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One episode of vertigo with audiometrically confirmed hearing loss and tinnitus: Incorrect. This defines a Probable case, not "Definite". A Definite diagnosis requires two or more vertigo episodes.

 

Option C. Histopathological confirmation of endolymphatic hydrops: Incorrect. This corresponds to "Certain" Ménière’s disease, which is only confirmed post-mortem via histopathology.

 

Option D. Episodic vertigo with no documented hearing loss: Incorrect. This fits the "Possible" category (vestibular variant), not "Definite".

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Definite" Ménière’s disease is diagnosed when a patient has ≥2 spontaneous vertigo episodes ≥20 minutes, documented hearing loss, tinnitus or fullness, and no other identifiable cause.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 103

choices.text: Advising the patient to avoid smoking and excess caffeine
Encouraging a low salt diet with sodium intake <2 g/day
Recommending high water intake to improve endolymph drainage
Advising patients to avoid activities requiring precise balance like flying or underwater diving

questions.text: Which of the following general measures is not typically recommended in the conservative management of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recommending high water intake to improve endolymph drainage

 

  • In fact, excess water intake is discouraged as it may worsen endolymphatic hydrops. Patients are advised to limit fluid intake moderately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advising the patient to avoid smoking and excess caffeine: Correct recommendation. Nicotine causes vasospasm, and caffeine aggravates symptoms — both should be avoided in Ménière’s disease.

 

Option B. Encouraging a low salt diet with sodium intake <2 g/day: Correct. Reducing salt helps decrease fluid retention and endolymphatic pressure, which improves symptoms in Ménière’s.

 

Option D. Advising patients to avoid activities requiring precise balance like flying or underwater diving: Correct. Sudden vertigo attacks in Ménière’s disease make flying, diving, or climbing dangerous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conservative management of Ménière’s disease includes low salt diet, cessation of smoking and caffeine, stress reduction, and avoiding activities requiring balance—excessive water intake is not recommended.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 103

choices.text: Administering intravenous diazepam to control vertigo and anxiety
Advising complete bed rest with head supported to minimize head movement
Encouraging the patient to walk periodically to regain vestibular compensation
Using vestibular suppressants like promethazine or dimenhydrinate via IM/IV route

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recommended measure in the acute management of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Encouraging the patient to walk periodically to regain vestibular compensation

 

  • During an acute attack, movement worsens symptoms. Vestibular compensation exercises are reserved for chronic stages, not acute management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administering intravenous diazepam to control vertigo and anxiety: Correct. Diazepam (Valium) has both vestibular suppressing and anxiolytic effects, making it useful during acute attacks.

 

Option B. Advising complete bed rest with head supported to minimize head movement: Correct. Minimizing head movement reduces exacerbation of vertigo during the acute phase.

 

Option D. Using vestibular suppressants like promethazine or dimenhydrinate via IM/IV route: Correct. Drugs like promethazine, prochlorperazine, and dimenhydrinate are effective vestibular sedatives used when oral administration isn’t feasible due to vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute attacks of Ménière’s disease are managed with reassurance, bed rest, vestibular suppressants, and vasodilators—movement should be minimized during the episode.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 103

choices.text: Betahistine acts by reducing cochlear fluid via inhibition of endolymph production
Vestibular suppressants like prochlorperazine are continued lifelong to prevent attacks
Elimination of allergens and correction of hormonal imbalances can help in preventing recurrent episodes
Furosemide should be used daily without potassium supplementation to maintain labyrinthine fluid balance

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the chronic phase management of Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elimination of allergens and correction of hormonal imbalances can help in preventing recurrent episodes

 

  • Identifying and eliminating food/inhalant allergens and treating conditions like hypothyroidism are part of chronic management, contributing to long-term control of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Betahistine acts by reducing cochlear fluid via inhibition of endolymph production: Incorrect. Betahistine is a vasodilator that improves labyrinthine blood flow by acting on histaminergic receptors, not by reducing endolymph production directly.

 

Option B. Vestibular suppressants like prochlorperazine are continued lifelong to prevent attacks: Incorrect. Prochlorperazine is used in the chronic phase for a limited duration (e.g., 2–3 months), not lifelong due to potential side effects.

 

Option D. Furosemide should be used daily without potassium supplementation to maintain labyrinthine fluid balance: Incorrect. Furosemide is used on alternate days with potassium supplementation to avoid hypokalemia and maintain electrolyte balance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the chronic phase of Ménière’s disease, identifying allergens and correcting hormonal imbalances (like hypothyroidism) play an important role in preventing recurrences.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 104

choices.text: Gentamicin is primarily cochleotoxic and commonly causes high-frequency SNHL
Microwick delivers drugs to the oval window through the tympanic membrane
Gentamicin therapy offers good vertigo control but carries a risk of hearing loss
Tympanostomy tube is inserted into the round window to allow Microwick placement

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding intratympanic gentamicin therapy for Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gentamicin therapy offers good vertigo control but carries a risk of hearing loss

 

  • Intratympanic gentamicin controls vertigo in 60–80% of patients, but carries a risk of sensorineural hearing loss in 4–30% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentamicin is primarily cochleotoxic and commonly causes high-frequency SNHL: Incorrect. Gentamicin is primarily vestibulotoxic, not cochleotoxic. Although hearing loss may occur, the main effect targets the vestibular labyrinth.

 

Option B. Microwick delivers drugs to the oval window through the tympanic membrane: Incorrect. The Micro wick delivers drugs to the round window, from where the medication is absorbed into the inner ear.

 

 

Option D. Tympanostomy tube is inserted into the round window to allow Microwick placement: Incorrect. The tympanostomy tube (grommet) is placed in the tympanic membrane, and the Micro wick is passed through it—not directly into the round window.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intratympanic gentamicin therapy is vestibulotoxic and provides effective vertigo control in Ménière’s disease but carries a significant risk of hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 104

choices.text: Endolymphatic sac decompression
Section of vestibular nerve
Labyrinthectomy
Cochleosacculotomy

questions.text: Which of the following surgical procedures for Ménière’s disease is considered destructive and results in complete loss of cochlear and vestibular function?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Labyrinthectomy

 

  • This is a destructive procedure used when cochlear function is non-serviceable. It involves complete destruction of the membranous labyrinth, thereby abolishing both hearing and balance function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endolymphatic sac decompression: This is a conservative procedure aimed at relieving excess endolymph pressure while preserving hearing. It is used when vertigo is disabling but cochlear function is still useful.

 

Option B. Section of vestibular nerve: Though it involves surgically sectioning the vestibular nerve, it is also considered a conservative option as it aims to control vertigo while preserving hearing.

 

Option D. Cochleosacculotomy: This is a conservative operation where the cochlear duct is punctured to decompress the endolymph, aiming to preserve cochlear function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Labyrinthectomy is a destructive surgical treatment for Ménière’s disease that eliminates both vestibular and cochlear function and is used only when hearing is not salvageable.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 104

choices.text: It delivers intermittent high-frequency electrical pulses directly to the cochlea
Myringotomy and ventilation tube insertion are required before using the device
The therapy is reserved for emergency control of acute vertigo episodes
It permanently destroys the vestibular labyrinth to control vertigo

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Meniett device therapy in the management of Ménière’s disease is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myringotomy and ventilation tube insertion are required before using the device

 

  • A ventilation tube must be inserted into the tympanic membrane via myringotomy to allow delivery of pressure waves from the Meniett device to the inner ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It delivers intermittent high-frequency electrical pulses directly to the cochlea: Incorrect. The Meniett device delivers low-pressure positive pressure waves, not electrical impulses, to the round window via the middle ear.

 

Option C. The therapy is reserved for emergency control of acute vertigo episodes: Incorrect. Meniett therapy is not for emergency use; it is a long-term home-based therapy used in chronic cases unresponsive to medical treatment.

 

Option D. It permanently destroys the vestibular labyrinth to control vertigo: Incorrect. Unlike gentamicin or labyrinthectomy, Meniett therapy is a non-destructive modality aimed at regulating endolymph pressure, not ablating the labyrinth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meniett device therapy delivers low-pressure pulses to the inner ear via a ventilation tube placed after myringotomy and is used in chronic Ménière’s disease cases unresponsive to medical treatment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 104

choices.text: It most commonly arises from the cochlear division of the 8th cranial nerve
It is a rapidly growing, malignant tumor of the cerebellopontine angle
Bilateral tumors are commonly seen in sporadic cases of acoustic neuroma
It is a benign tumor arising from Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve and grows slowly

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a benign tumor arising from Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve and grows slowly

 

  • The tumor arises from Schwann cells of the vestibular division of the 8th cranial nerve and has a slow-growing, benign nature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It most commonly arises from the cochlear division of the 8th cranial nerve: Incorrect. The tumor almost always arises from the vestibular division, not the cochlear division.

 

Option B. It is a rapidly growing, malignant tumor of the cerebellopontine angle: Incorrect. Acoustic neuroma is benign and extremely slow-growing, often taking years to become symptomatic.

 

Option C. Bilateral tumors are commonly seen in sporadic cases of acoustic neuroma: Incorrect. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are seen in neurofibromatosis type II, not in sporadic cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuroma is a benign, slow-growing tumor arising from Schwann cells of the vestibular division of the VIII cranial nerve and may be bilateral in neurofibromatosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 112

choices.text: Bilateral conductive hearing loss with tinnitus
Sudden onset vertigo with bilateral nystagmus
Unilateral progressive sensorineural hearing loss with impaired speech discrimination
Facial nerve palsy as an early symptom

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unilateral progressive sensorineural hearing loss with impaired speech discrimination

 

  • The most common and earliest presenting symptom is unilateral progressive SNHL, often disproportionate speech discrimination loss, which is characteristic of acoustic neuroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral conductive hearing loss with tinnitus: Incorrect. Acoustic neuroma typically causes unilateral and sensorineural, not conductive, hearing loss. Conductive loss is seen in middle ear pathologies.

 

Option B. Sudden onset vertigo with bilateral nystagmus: Incorrect. Though imbalance may occur, true vertigo is uncommon in acoustic neuroma. Nystagmus is not a typical early feature.

 

Option D. Facial nerve palsy as an early symptom: Incorrect. While VIIth nerve involvement can occur, motor fibers are affected late. Early features involve sensory fibers (e.g., Hitzelberger’s sign).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuroma typically presents with unilateral progressive sensorineural hearing loss and disproportionately poor speech discrimination.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 112

choices.text: Pure tone audiometry
CT scan with contrast
MRI with gadolinium contrast
Evoked response audiometry (BERA)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the gold standard investigation for diagnosing an intracanalicular acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MRI with gadolinium contrast

 

  • This is the most sensitive and specific investigation and is the gold standard for diagnosing even a few mm-sized acoustic neuromas within the internal auditory canal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure tone audiometry: Incorrect. It shows sensorineural hearing loss, especially in high frequencies, but cannot localize the lesion or differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear causes.

 

 

Option B. CT scan with contrast: Incorrect. CT is useful, especially when combined with air or contrast, but may miss very small intracanalicular tumours.

 

Option D. Evoked response audiometry (BERA): Incorrect. It helps screen retrocochlear lesions and shows delay in wave V, but not as accurate as MRI in localizing and confirming the tumour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for detecting intracanalicular acoustic neuroma.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 113

choices.text: Conventional radiotherapy is the primary treatment of choice for all acoustic neuromas.
Middle cranial fossa approach is preferred for large tumours with non-serviceable hearing.
Gamma knife surgery is a stereotactic radiosurgery used in selected cases of acoustic neuroma.
Cyber knife requires a rigid frame fixed to the skull during treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of acoustic neuroma is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gamma knife surgery is a stereotactic radiosurgery used in selected cases of acoustic neuroma.

 

  • Gamma knife is a non-invasive stereotactic radiotherapy option, used when surgery is refused, contraindicated, or for residual tumours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conventional radiotherapy is the primary treatment of choice for all acoustic neuromas.: Incorrect. Conventional external beam radiotherapy is not preferred due to low CNS tolerance to radiation and is not effective for acoustic neuromas.

 

Option B. Middle cranial fossa approach is preferred for large tumours with non-serviceable hearing.: Incorrect. Middle cranial fossa approach is typically used for small tumours where hearing preservation is intended.

 

Option D. Cyber knife requires a rigid frame fixed to the skull during treatment.: Incorrect. Cyber knife is an improvement over gamma knife and is frameless, using real-time image guidance and robotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma knife stereotactic radiosurgery is a treatment option in patients with acoustic neuroma who are not surgical candidates or have residual tumour.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 114

choices.text: Michel Aplasia – Incomplete partitioning of cochlea with preserved petrous apex
Scheibe Dysplasia – Complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth
Alexander Dysplasia – Affects basal turn of cochlea causing high-frequency hearing loss
Bing–Siebenmann Dysplasia – Cochleosaccular dysplasia with normal utricle and semicircular canals

questions.text: Which of the following congenital inner ear anomalies is correctly matched with its description?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alexander Dysplasia – Affects basal turn of cochlea causing high-frequency hearing loss

 

  • Alexander dysplasia affects only the basal turn of the membranous cochlea, leading to high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Low-frequency hearing is preserved and may be aided with hearing devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel Aplasia – Incomplete partitioning of cochlea with preserved petrous apex: Incorrect. Michel aplasia is complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth, not incomplete partition. Even the petrous apex is absent, making hearing restoration impossible.

 

Option B. Scheibe Dysplasia – Complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth: Incorrect. Scheibe dysplasia is a cochleosaccular dysplasia with normal bony labyrinth, and utricle and semicircular canals are preserved, not absent.

 

Option D. Bing–Siebenmann Dysplasia – Cochleosaccular dysplasia with normal utricle and semicircular canals:  Incorrect. This anomaly involves complete absence of the membranous labyrinth, not a selective cochleosaccular defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alexander dysplasia is a congenital inner ear anomaly affecting only the basal turn of the cochlea, resulting in high-frequency hearing loss with preserved low-frequency hearing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 115

choices.text: Rubella infection during pregnancy
Radiation exposure in the first trimester
Administration of amikacin during pregnancy
Iron supplementation in third trimester

questions.text: Which of the following maternal factors is least likely to cause congenital hearing loss in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron supplementation in third trimester
