  • Iron is not teratogenic and is actually beneficial during pregnancy. It does not contribute to hearing loss and is essential to prevent maternal and fetal anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella infection during pregnancy: Incorrect. Rubella is a part of the TORCHES group of infections, which are well-known causes of sensorineural hearing loss in the developing fetus.

 

Option B. Radiation exposure in the first trimester: Incorrect. Radiation during organogenesis (especially in the first trimester) can have teratogenic effects, including hearing loss.

 

Option C. Administration of amikacin during pregnancy: Incorrect. Amikacin, an aminoglycoside, is ototoxic and crosses the placenta, leading to cochlear damage in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TORCH infections, ototoxic drugs like aminoglycosides, radiation, and maternal metabolic disorders are significant maternal factors associated with congenital hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 115

choices.text: Pendred syndrome
Waardenburg syndrome
Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome
Usher syndrome

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with congenital sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) and has a history of syncopal episodes. ECG shows a prolonged QT interval. Which of the following syndromes is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome

 

  • This is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by congenital SNHL along with cardiac arrhythmias (prolonged QT interval) and syncopal attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pendred syndrome: Incorrect. Pendred syndrome causes congenital SNHL associated with nontoxic goitre and a defect in iodine organification (positive perchlorate discharge test), not syncopal episodes.

 

Option B. Waardenburg syndrome: Incorrect. This syndrome presents with white forelock, heterochromia iridis, vitiligo, and dystopia canthorum, along with SNHL. However, ECG changes or syncope are not features.

 

 

Option D. Usher syndrome: Incorrect. Usher syndrome presents with delayed SNHL and retinitis pigmentosa, not congenital deafness or cardiac issues.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder presenting with congenital SNHL and prolonged QT interval on ECG, often leading to syncopal episodes.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 116

choices.text: Treacher-Collins syndrome
Alport syndrome
Crouzon syndrome
Apert syndrome

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with progressive sensorineural hearing loss and a history of hereditary nephritis. His family history reveals multiple male relatives with similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alport syndrome

 

  • Alport syndrome is characterized by progressive SNHL, hereditary glomerulonephritis, and corneal dystrophy. It typically follows an X-linked or autosomal dominant pattern and often presents in males during late childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treacher-Collins syndrome: Incorrect. This syndrome features conductive hearing loss, facial bone hypoplasia, coloboma of eyelids, microtia, and meatal atresia but no renal involvement.

 

 

Option C. Crouzon syndrome: Incorrect. It is associated with craniofacial dysostosis, frog-eye appearance, and conductive or mixed hearing loss, but renal or corneal features are absent.

 

 

Option D. Apert syndrome: Incorrect. Apert syndrome includes syndactyly and features of Crouzon syndrome, including conductive hearing loss due to stapes fixation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome presents with progressive sensorineural hearing loss, hereditary nephritis, and corneal dystrophy, typically inherited in an X-linked or autosomal dominant pattern.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 116

choices.text: Stickler syndrome
Klippel-Feil syndrome
Branchio-oto-renal syndrome
Wildervanck syndrome

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with branchial fistulas, malformed external ears with preauricular pits, and renal anomalies. Audiometry reveals mixed hearing loss. Which of the following syndromes is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Branchio-oto-renal syndrome

 

  • It is characterized by conductive or mixed hearing loss, branchial fistulas or cysts, preauricular pits, and renal anomalies, fitting the full clinical picture given.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stickler syndrome: Incorrect. While Stickler syndrome may involve conductive or SNHL along with facial abnormalities like small jaw, cleft palate, myopia, and retinal detachment, it does not involve branchial fistulas or renal anomalies.

 

 

Option B. Klippel-Feil syndrome: Incorrect. Presents with short neck, fused cervical vertebrae, and may include SNHL or mixed hearing loss, but renal and branchial anomalies are absent.

 

 

Option D. Wildervanck syndrome: Incorrect. Associated with Klippel-Feil, CN VI palsy, and SNHL, but renal and branchial anomalies are not features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Branchio-oto-renal syndrome presents with conductive or mixed hearing loss, branchial cysts or fistulas, malformed external ears with preauricular pits, and renal abnormalities.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 116

choices.text: Van der Hoeve syndrome
Goldenhar syndrome
Down syndrome
Pierre-Robin sequence

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with a history of cleft palate and micrognathia presents with sensorineural hearing loss. Examination reveals glossoptosis and features suggestive of Stickler syndrome. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pierre-Robin sequence

 

This syndrome is defined by micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate, and often involves sensorineural or conductive hearing loss. It may also be part of Stickler syndrome, which fits the presentation.

 

 

Other Options:

Option A. Van der Hoeve syndrome: Incorrect. This is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and delayed-onset hearing loss that may be conductive, sensorineural, or mixed like otosclerosis. Micrognathia and cleft palate are not classical features.

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Incorrect. Presents with facial asymmetry, preauricular tags/pits, low set ears, and vertebral anomalies. Hearing loss is usually mixed or conductive, but cleft palate and micrognathia are not key features.

 

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Incorrect. Characterized by conductive hearing loss, mental retardation, and serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube dysfunction. Although there may be craniofacial anomalies, cleft palate and glossoptosis are not typical.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pierre-Robin sequence is characterized by micrognathia, glossoptosis, cleft palate, and hearing loss (SNHL or conductive), and may be part of Stickler syndrome.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 116

Radiation exposure during the first trimester
Administration of paracetamol during third trimester

questions.text: Which of the following maternal factors is not associated with congenital hearing loss in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Administration of paracetamol during third trimester

 

Paracetamol is considered safe in pregnancy and does not cause ototoxicity or congenital hearing loss. It is not mentioned as a teratogenic factor affecting the fetal ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maternal rubella infection during pregnancy: Incorrect. Rubella is part of the TORCHES group of infections (Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, CMV, Herpes, Syphilis) that can cross the placenta and affect the fetus, often leading to sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option B. Use of aminoglycosides like gentamicin during pregnancy: Incorrect. Drugs such as streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, and amikacin are ototoxic and can cross the placenta to damage the fetal cochlea, leading to congenital hearing loss.

 

Option C. Radiation exposure during the first trimester: Incorrect. Radiation to the mother in early pregnancy can interfere with the development of the fetal auditory system, making it a known risk factor for hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal infections (TORCHES), ototoxic drugs (like aminoglycosides), radiation in the first trimester, and maternal illness (e.g., diabetes, alcoholism) are associated with congenital hearing loss in the fetus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 115

choices.text: Forceps delivery
Neonatal jaundice with bilirubin >20 mg%
Use of paracetamol for neonatal fever
Birth weight of 2.8 kg

questions.text: Which of the following perinatal conditions is most likely to cause sensorineural hearing loss due to damage to cochlear nuclei?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neonatal jaundice with bilirubin >20 mg%

 

High bilirubin levels (>20 mg%) are toxic to the cochlear nuclei and can cause sensorineural hearing loss. This is a well-established perinatal cause of hearing impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps delivery: Incorrect. Although birth injuries like forceps delivery can cause intracranial hemorrhage with blood extravasation into the inner ear, it is not the most direct or consistent cause of cochlear nuclei damage when compared to severe jaundice.

 

Option C. Use of paracetamol for neonatal fever: Incorrect. Paracetamol is not ototoxic and is considered safe in neonates. It is not a known contributor to hearing loss.

 

Option D. Birth weight of 2.8 kg: Incorrect. Low birth weight is defined as <1500 g (i.e., <1.5 kg). A birth weight of 2.8 kg is normal and not considered a perinatal risk factor for hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perinatal causes like neonatal jaundice with bilirubin >20 mg%, anoxia, prematurity, sepsis, and ototoxic drugs can damage the cochlear nuclei and lead to sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 117

choices.text: Secretory otitis media
Familial progressive sensorineural deafness
Perilymph fistula following head trauma
Acute mumps infection

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with progressive bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. There is a positive family history of deafness. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this child’s hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial progressive sensorineural deafness

 

A genetic cause of postnatal hearing loss, this condition presents as progressive bilateral SNHL in childhood or adulthood and may occur alone or as part of syndromes like Alport, Hurler, or Klippel-Feil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secretory otitis media: Incorrect. This condition causes conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural. It is more often transient and related to Eustachian tube dysfunction.

 

Option C. Perilymph fistula following head trauma: Incorrect. While trauma (like temporal bone fractures) can cause sudden SNHL due to perilymph leak, the case described is progressive and familial, making a genetic cause more likely.

 

Option D. Acute mumps infection: Incorrect. Mumps may cause sudden unilateral SNHL, not a bilateral progressive loss with family history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postnatal genetic causes like familial progressive sensorineural deafness often present in childhood with bilateral progressive SNHL and may occur alone or with syndromes such as Alport or Hurler.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 117

choices.text: Antoni A and Antoni B areas with Verocay bodies
Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies
Pseudopalisading necrosis
Whorled pattern with psammoma bodies

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss and imbalance. MRI reveals a well-circumscribed mass at the cerebellopontine angle. Histopathological examination (as shown in the image) reveals spindle-shaped cells arranged in fascicles with alternating hypercellular and hypocellular areas. Which of the following histological features best describes this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antoni A and Antoni B areas with Verocay bodies

 

The image is a classic H&E-stained histopathological section of Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma), showing:

 

  • Antoni A areas: Hypercellular, spindle-shaped Schwann cells arranged in palisades.
  • Antoni B areas: Hypocellular regions with a loose, myxoid background.
  • Verocay bodies: Rows of palisading nuclei separated by anuclear zones – characteristic of Antoni A regions.

 

These findings are hallmark features of schwannomas, especially vestibular schwannoma, commonly arising from the vestibular division of CN VIII.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies: Incorrect – These are seen in pilocytic astrocytomas, typically in children and located in the cerebellum.

 

 

Option C. Pseudopalisading necrosis: Incorrect – Seen in glioblastoma multiforme, a high-grade astrocytoma characterized by central necrosis surrounded by radially arranged tumor cells.

 

 

Option D. Whorled pattern with psammoma bodies: Incorrect – Seen in meningiomas, especially those attached to the dura. Psammoma bodies are concentric calcifications.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuroma shows spindle cells arranged in Antoni A and B areas with Verocay bodies on histology.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 112

choices.text: CN V – Loss of taste confirmed by electrogustometry
CN VII – Hitselberger sign
CN IX – Decreased corneal sensation
CN VIII – Dysdiadochokinesia

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with unilateral hearing loss, decreased corneal reflex, and numbness over the face. On further examination, lacrimation is reduced (confirmed by Schirmer test), and hypoesthesia is noted over the posterior wall of the external auditory canal (Hitselberger sign). As the tumor progresses, the patient also develops ataxia and signs of raised intracranial pressure. Which of the following cranial nerve involvements is correctly matched with the associated sign or test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CN VII – Hitselberger sign

 

Supplies the posterior wall of the external auditory canal, and hypoesthesia here is termed Hitselberger sign, often the first sign of facial nerve involvement.
Also responsible for lacrimation (Schirmer test) and anterior 2/3 taste (electrogustometry).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CN V – Loss of taste confirmed by electrogustometry: Controls facial sensation and corneal reflex (afferent limb). Decreased corneal reflex and facial numbness are early signs of its involvement in acoustic neuroma. Loss of taste is not associated with CN V — incorrect match in option A.

 

Option C. CN IX – Decreased corneal sensation: Responsible for dysphagia and hoarseness, not corneal sensation — option C is incorrect.

 

Option D. CN VIII – Dysdiadochokinesia: Cerebellar signs like dysdiadochokinesia, ataxia, and past-pointing result from tumor compression of the cerebellum, not from CN VIII itself — option D is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hitselberger sign (posterior canal hypoesthesia) is an early indicator of facial nerve (CN VII) involvement in acoustic neuroma.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 112

choices.text: Krause’s line
Donaldson’s line
Trautmann’s triangle
House–Brackmann line

questions.text: During endolymphatic sac decompression surgery for Meniere’s disease, a line is drawn in the plane of the lateral semicircular canal and extended posteriorly. This line helps identify the location of the endolymphatic sac. What is the name of this anatomical landmark?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Donaldson’s line

 

  • It is a surgical landmark used during endolymphatic sac decompression.
    • A line drawn along the plane of the lateral semicircular canal posteriorly will bisect the posterior semicircular canal, and when extended further, helps localize the endolymphatic sac just below the line.
    • This is critical in avoiding injury during surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Krause’s line: Incorrect. This is not an anatomical landmark used in otologic surgery.

 

Option C. Trautmann’s triangle: Incorrect. It is an area bounded by the sigmoid sinus, posterior semicircular canal, and superior petrosal sinus, used in trans labyrinthine approaches but not specifically for identifying the endolymphatic sac.

 

Option D. House–Brackmann line: Incorrect. Not an anatomical line; House–Brackmann is a grading system used to assess facial nerve function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Donaldson’s line is the surgical landmark for locating the endolymphatic sac during decompression, drawn along the lateral semicircular canal and extending posteriorly.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 104

choices.text: Cochlear nerve lies in the posterosuperior quadrant of the IAC
Facial nerve lies in the anterosuperior quadrant of the IAC
Inferior vestibular nerve lies in the anterosuperior quadrant of the IAC
Bill’s bar separates superior and inferior vestibular nerves

questions.text: A NEET-PG aspirant is revising the anatomy of the internal auditory canal (IAC). Which of the following correctly describes the contents and landmarks of the IAC?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve lies in the anterosuperior quadrant of the IAC

 

Facial nerve lies in the anterosuperior quadrant of the IAC: Correct – It is located anterosuperiorly and is separated from the superior vestibular nerve by Bill’s bar.

 

The internal auditory canal (IAC) is anatomically divided into 4 quadrants by two bony structures:

 

  • Falciform crest (horizontal): Separates upper (superior) and lower (inferior) nerves.
  • Bill’s bar (vertical): Separates facial nerve from superior vestibular nerve.

 

Quadrant-wise arrangement in the IAC:

 

  • Anterosuperior: Facial nerve 
  • Anteroinferior: Cochlear nerve
  • Posterosuperior: Superior vestibular nerve (from macula of utricle, cristae of superior & lateral canals)
  • Posteroinferior: Inferior vestibular nerve (from macula of saccule and crista of posterior canal)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear nerve lies in the posterosuperior quadrant of the IAC: Incorrect. It lies in the anteroinferior quadrant.

 

Option C. Inferior vestibular nerve lies in the anterosuperior quadrant of the IAC: Incorrect. It lies posteroinferiorly.

 

Option D. Bill’s bar separates superior and inferior vestibular nerves: Incorrect. Bill’s bar separates the facial nerve (anterosuperior) from the superior vestibular nerve (posterosuperior).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Facial nerve lies in the anterosuperior quadrant of the internal auditory canal and is separated from the superior vestibular nerve by Bill’s bar.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 128
